If our sources were unresolved on scales <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn60.gif\" alt=\"$\\lt 50$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\lt 50</script></span></span> k<em>\u03bb</em>, then this would be equivalent to reporting the maximum pixel value in the images; in practice, many of our sources still show some structure on these scales.</p><p>In the left panel of Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaa2662f4\">4</a>, we compare the total flux densities of the ALMA sources determined in this way to the LABOCA measurements (Wei\u00df et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib80\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib80\">2013</a>). Note that we have made no effort to correct for the different bandwidths of the two instruments (8 versus ~60 GHz). We recover a median of (91 \u00b1 24)% of the LABOCA flux density, consistent within the mutual absolute flux scaling uncertainties (~10% for both instruments). Meanwhile, the middle panel of Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaa2662f4\">4</a> shows no clear trend in the fraction of flux recovered as a function of LABOCA flux density. These plots suggest that, in general, the ALMA data do not resolve out significant extended emission or hide a large population of sources too faint to detect individually. Hodge et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib40\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib40\">2013</a>) reached a similar conclusion using ALMA to image a large sample of unlensed 870 <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn61.gif\" alt=\"$\\mu {\\rm{m}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mu {\\rm{m}}</script></span></span>-selected sources discovered by LABOCA in the Extended <em>Chandra</em> Deep Field-South. The sample of SPT DSFGs observed in this work shows a better degree of consistency between the ALMA and LABOCA flux densities, which may be due to the fact that the SPT-selected sources are apparently brighter. Indeed, the brightest sources studied by Hodge et al. correspond to the faintest sources in the present sample.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apjaa2662f4\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjaa2662f4\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662f4_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 4.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 4.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662f4_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 4.</strong>\u00a0Extent to which flux densities derived from ALMA, LABOCA, and the lens models agree; see Section <a class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjaa2662s4-2\">4.2</a> for details. In all three panels, solid lines indicate perfect agreement between the flux density measurements being compared. Left: the ALMA data recover a median of 91% of the single-dish flux density measured by LABOCA, indicated by the dashed line. Middle: no clear trend is seen in the fraction of flux detected by ALMA as a function of LABOCA flux density. Right: the lens models of all sources contain a median of 102% of the total ALMA flux density.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apjaa2662f4\" href=\"/0004-637X/826/2/112/downloadFigure/figure/apjaa2662f4\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apjaa2662f4\" href=\"/0004-637X/826/2/112/downloadHRFigure/figure/apjaa2662f4\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><p>We also test the extent to which the total ALMA flux densities agree with the total flux densities inferred from the lens models. In this case, we define the total model flux density as the sum over all components of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn62.gif\" alt=\"${S}_{870\\mu {\\rm{m}}}\\times {\\mu }_{870\\mu {\\rm{m}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{S}_{870\\mu {\\rm{m}}}\\times {\\mu }_{870\\mu {\\rm{m}}}</script></span></span>. This is shown in the right panel of Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaa2662f4\">4</a>. The models contain a median of 102% of the total ALMA flux densities, indicating that no significant sources of emission remain unaccounted for by the models. As the residual maps generated by the best-fit models shown in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaa2662f2\">2</a> show no significant remaining peaks, this is unsurprising.</p></div><h3 id=\"apjaa2662s4-3\" name=\"apjaa2662s4-3\">4.3.\u00a0Multiplicity in the SPT Sample</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>Several high-resolution ALMA follow-up studies of submillimeter sources originally detected in low-resolution, single-dish surveys have concluded that a significant fraction of the sources break up into multiple components when observed at higher resolution. In the ALESS program, Hodge et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib40\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib40\">2013</a>) find that at least 35% of their sources contain multiple components, but that these components are consistent with being distributed randomly on the sky. In contrast, Bussmann et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib13\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib13\">2015</a>) report a multiplicity fraction of 69%, with the multiple sources strongly concentrated at separations <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn63.gif\" alt=\"$\\lesssim 3$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\lesssim 3</script></span></span>''. Similarly, Simpson et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib64\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib64\">2015</a>) report that 61% of SCUBA-2 sources contain multiple components.</p><p>Our ability to determine multiplicity fractions from the follow-up of SPT-selected sources is hampered by two potential issues. First, the large majority of the sources considered here are strongly lensed. This makes finding close-in multiple components difficult, as any faint nearby companions will be overwhelmed by the much brighter lensed emission. Second, the SPT sources have a much higher apparent brightness compared to the unlensed single-dish sources observed in other follow-up campaigns. This reduces our ability to detect faint sources, as low-level phase errors can create spurious \"companions.\" For this reason, we use a higher (5<em>\u03c3</em>, with <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn64.gif\" alt=\"${\\sigma }_{870\\mu {\\rm{m}}}\\sim 0.18\\mbox{--}0.5$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\sigma }_{870\\mu {\\rm{m}}}\\sim 0.18\\mbox{--}0.5</script></span></span> mJy) threshold for source detection than other source catalogs. We also refrain from counting sources which require multiple source-plane components to reproduce the lensed emission as multiples, because these components are generally separated by <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn65.gif\" alt=\"$\\lt 0\\buildrel{\\prime\\prime}\\over{.} 5$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\lt 0\\buildrel{\\prime\\prime}\\over{.} 5</script></span></span>, and the source-plane components are likely an approximation of complex underlying structure within a single galaxy.</p><p>In the ALMA data presented here, only 13% (6/47) of sources contain multiple components at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn66.gif\" alt=\"$\\gt 5\\sigma $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\gt 5\\sigma</script></span></span> significance. This fraction is significantly lower than the high multiplicity rates reported by other ALMA follow-up programs. While obviously dependent on the depth of the follow-up observations, the high reported multiplicity fractions in other programs come from data with depth and resolution roughly comparable to the ALMA data presented here (ALESS detection threshold <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn67.gif\" alt=\"$\\sim 1.1\\mbox{--}2.1$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\sim 1.1\\mbox{--}2.1</script></span></span> mJy, compared to <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn68.gif\" alt=\"$\\sim 0.9\\mbox{--}2.5$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\sim 0.9\\mbox{--}2.5</script></span></span> mJy here). After considering our lack of sensitivity to close-in sources and a higher source detection threshold, the ALESS sample is the most natural comparison sample\u2014the higher detection threshold in our data is balanced by the increased depth of our observations, and both samples are insensitive to multiples at separations of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn69.gif\" alt=\"$\\lesssim 1\\buildrel{\\prime\\prime}\\over{.} 5$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\lesssim 1\\buildrel{\\prime\\prime}\\over{.} 5</script></span></span>. While the overall multiplicity fraction does appear to be lower in the SPT sample, the few multiples in our data are consistent with being uniformly distributed within the fields, as in the ALESS data.</p></div></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apjaa2662s5\" name=\"apjaa2662s5\">5.\u00a0DISCUSSION</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>We are now in a position to take advantage of the comprehensive follow-up programs we have been conducting to revisit a number of topics of interest which may be investigated further using our new knowledge of source sizes.</p><h3 id=\"apjaa2662s5-1\" name=\"apjaa2662s5-1\">5.1.\u00a0Reliability of Lens Models</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>For the four sources studied by Hezaveh et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib37\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib37\">2013</a>) using low-resolution (~1<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />5) data, we find generally good agreement with the updated models. The differences between the previous and updated models can be entirely explained by the difference in background source parameterization\u2014that is, fitting only the data used by Hezaveh et al. with elliptical source-plane components recovers the models presented here, while fitting all of the data used in this work with the circularly symmetric Gaussian components assumed by Hezaveh et al. recovers the models shown there. This indicates that the model uncertainties on the properties of the background sources are dominated by systematic, rather than statistical, uncertainty. We have attempted to counter this issue by use of the DIC for model selection, which effectively penalizes models with more degrees of freedom unless they reproduce the data significantly better.</p><p>ALMA is now capable of resolutions as fine as a few tens of milliarcseconds. To what extent can we expect that the model properties (e.g., <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn70.gif\" alt=\"${\\mu }_{870\\mu {\\rm{m}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\mu }_{870\\mu {\\rm{m}}}</script></span></span>) derived here would agree with the properties derived from observations with the ~20<b>&#x00d7;</b> better resolution now possible? Given that the true source structure of DSFGs is expected to be clumpy and irregular (e.g., Swinbank et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib72\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib72\">2011</a>; Dye et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib27\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib27\">2015</a>), in contrast to the smooth source parameterization assumed here, this question is difficult to answer. This irregular structure means that different regions of a given source will be magnified by different amounts, as opposed to the magnifications derived here, which are averaged over the assumed-elliptical source profile.</p><p>One instructive comparison comes via the ALMA Long Baseline Campaign observations of the lensed DSFG SDP.81 at ~0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />023 resolution (ALMA Partnership et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib1\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib1\">2015</a>). This source was also included in the sample studied by Bussmann et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib12\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib12\">2013</a>), who used ~0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />5\u20131'' SMA observations to construct the lens models, comparable to the resolution of the ALMA data used in this work. Note, however, that the SMA observations reached only a peak signal to noise of 12 for SDP.81, which is far less than the typical significance of our detections (median peak signal to noise of 62). The lens model, which also represented the background source as an elliptical S\u00e9rsic profile, as in this work, yielded a magnification of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn71.gif\" alt=\"${\\mu }_{870\\mu {\\rm{m}}}\\sim 11$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\mu }_{870\\mu {\\rm{m}}}\\sim 11</script></span></span>. Several authors have constructed lens models of the continuum emission using the high-resolution ALMA observations of SDP.81, finding magnifications <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn72.gif\" alt=\"${\\mu }_{870\\mu {\\rm{m}}}\\sim 16\\mbox{--}22$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\mu }_{870\\mu {\\rm{m}}}\\sim 16\\mbox{--}22</script></span></span> using pixelated source-plane reconstructions (Dye et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib27\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib27\">2015</a>; Rybak et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib60\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib60\">2015</a>; Tamura et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib74\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib74\">2015</a>). It is difficult to know whether these ~50% variations are to be generally expected, or whether the differences arise chiefly from data resolution, data signal to noise, or modeling approach. In at least this single case, however, shrinking the beam area by <img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/gsim.gif\" alt=\"gsim\" align=\"baseline\" />100<b>&#x00d7;</b> leads to less than factor of two changes in the model source-averaged magnification.</p></div><h3 id=\"apjaa2662s5-2\" name=\"apjaa2662s5-2\">5.2.\u00a0Size Distribution of Background Sources</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>Gravitational lensing allows us to study the background sources at effective resolutions higher than the instrumental resolution of our observations. It is worth considering, however, the biases which may be present when comparing lensed and unlensed samples. For example, numerous authors have explored a potential size bias of lensed samples (e.g., Hezaveh et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib38\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib38\">2012</a>; Serjeant <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib62\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib62\">2012</a>; Wardlow et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib79\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib79\">2013</a>), in which sources with high magnification are preferentially smaller than sources with lower magnification factors. This effect is due to the angular extent of the background source in comparison to the relatively small region near caustics over which high magnification is possible\u2014small sources near caustics can experience a higher net magnification compared to more extended sources. Different regions of a given background source experience different magnifications, depending on the lensing geometry, an effect known as differential magnification.</p><p>We explore this effect in the left panel of Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaa2662f5\">5</a>. Here, we show the source magnification as a function of its size for both the SPT sample and the <em>Herschel</em>-selected samples of Bussmann et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib12\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib12\">2013</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib13\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib13\">2015</a>). Many of the lens models reproduce the complex background source morphology by invoking multiple S\u00e9rsic components. These components are likely to be physically associated, so we show the total flux-weighted magnification and the total source area of all related components (so the two components of, e.g., SPT0103-45 are shown as a single point, while the two components of, e.g., SPT0128-51 are shown separately). We find a median intrinsic FWHM of 0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />28. This figure shows no clear correlation between the two parameters. However, in agreement with the size bias mentioned, it does appear that the sources with the highest magnifications are preferentially smaller than sources with lower magnifications. In other words, small size appears to be a necessary but not sufficient criterion for the highest magnifications.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apjaa2662f5\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjaa2662f5\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662f5_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 5.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 5.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662f5_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 5.</strong>\u00a0Left: intrinsic source size plotted as a function of 870 <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn73.gif\" alt=\"$\\mu {\\rm{m}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mu {\\rm{m}}</script></span></span>\u00a0magnification, for all sources in the SPT and <em>Herschel</em> DSFG samples. Sources with the highest magnifications are preferentially more compact than the full sample. Right: size distributions of strongly lensed (<span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn74.gif\" alt=\"${\\mu }_{870\\mu {\\rm{m}}}\\gt 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\mu }_{870\\mu {\\rm{m}}}\\gt 2</script></span></span>) SPT and <em>Herschel</em> sources (Bussmann et al. <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib12\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib12\">2013</a>, <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib13\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib13\">2015</a>) compared to samples of unlensed DSFGs observed by ALMA from the 850 <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn75.gif\" alt=\"$\\mu {\\rm{m}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mu {\\rm{m}}</script></span></span>-selected SCUBA-2 Cosmology Legacy Survey (Simpson et al. <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib64\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib64\">2015</a>) and AzTEC 1.1 mm-selected sources (Ikarashi et al. <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib44\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib44\">2015</a>). For all samples, we plot the circularized FWHM; J. Simpson et al. (2016, private communication) report only source major axes, so we have circularized their measurements assuming an average axis ratio of 0.8. This figure indicates that the lensed samples recover the same size distribution as the unlensed samples, despite the potential size bias shown in the left panel.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apjaa2662f5\" href=\"/0004-637X/826/2/112/downloadFigure/figure/apjaa2662f5\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apjaa2662f5\" href=\"/0004-637X/826/2/112/downloadHRFigure/figure/apjaa2662f5\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><p>A separate but related question is whether selecting strongly lensed sources results in a biased measurement of the true size distribution of DSFGs (e.g., Hezaveh et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib38\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib38\">2012</a>). Even though high-magnification sources are preferentially compact, the size distribution of lensed samples is not necessarily biased, depending on the true underlying brightness and size distributions (for example, if the true size distribution were a delta function, no bias would exist). The presence of such a bias can be investigated by comparing size distributions measured from lensed and unlensed samples. In the right panel of Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaa2662f5\">5</a>, we compare the size distribution measured from the strongly lensed (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn76.gif\" alt=\"${\\mu }_{870\\mu {\\rm{m}}}\\gt 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\mu }_{870\\mu {\\rm{m}}}\\gt 2</script></span></span>) sources in the SPT and <em>Herschel</em> samples with two unlensed DSFG samples. Simpson et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib64\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib64\">2015</a>) measure sizes of 22 sources based on 870 <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn77.gif\" alt=\"$\\mu {\\rm{m}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mu {\\rm{m}}</script></span></span>\u00a0ALMA imaging of objects selected from the 850 <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn78.gif\" alt=\"$\\mu {\\rm{m}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mu {\\rm{m}}</script></span></span>\u00a0SCUBA-2 Cosmology Legacy Survey (Geach et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib30\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib30\">2013</a>). Only one source was unresolved by these data, with a FWHM <img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/lesssim.gif\" alt=\"lesssim\" align=\"baseline\" /> 0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />18, although the sample is restricted to sources with <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn79.gif\" alt=\"${S}_{870\\mu {\\rm{m}}}\\sim 5\\mbox{--}12$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{S}_{870\\mu {\\rm{m}}}\\sim 5\\mbox{--}12</script></span></span> mJy to ensure sufficient signal-to-noise to measure an accurate source size. Ikarashi et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib44\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib44\">2015</a>) report 1.1 mm sizes from ALMA observations of 13 AzTEC 1.1 mm-selected objects spanning <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn80.gif\" alt=\"${S}_{1.1\\mathrm{mm}}\\,\\sim \\,1.2\\mbox{--}3.5$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{S}_{1.1\\mathrm{mm}}\\,\\sim \\,1.2\\mbox{--}3.5</script></span></span> mJy. Assuming a dust emissivity index <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn81.gif\" alt=\"$\\beta =2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\beta =2</script></span></span>, this corresponds to <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn82.gif\" alt=\"${S}_{870\\mu {\\rm{m}}}\\sim 3\\mbox{--}9$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{S}_{870\\mu {\\rm{m}}}\\sim 3\\mbox{--}9</script></span></span> mJy. Even after accounting for the gravitational magnification, the SPT sources are typically brighter than many of the unlensed comparison sources, although no significant correlations between source flux density and size are seen in either unlensed sample or our own. Both unlensed samples have sizes measured from the dust continuum emission, eliminating possible confusion in comparing to sizes measured with alternative methods (e.g., from the radio continuum; Biggs et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib7\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib7\">2011</a>).</p><p>Given the present sample sizes, both samples of strongly lensed sources have size distributions consistent with the distribution of unlensed sources. The two-sample K\u2013S test confirms that we cannot reject the hypothesis that both distributions are drawn from the same parent distribution (<em>p</em> = 0.84). Few of the unlensed sources have robust spectroscopic redshifts, which hinders our ability to infer whether or not the consistent angular size distributions correspond to differing physical size distributions. As detailed in B\u00e9thermin et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib6\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib6\">2015</a>) and Strandet et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib71\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib71\">2016</a>), we expect more sources at higher redshifts in the SPT sample due to its long selection wavelength and preferential selection of lensed sources. We note, however, that the angular size scale evolves slowly for <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn83.gif\" alt=\"$z\\gt 2;$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\gt 2;</script></span></span> the difference in the size scale between the SPT median redshift and the median redshift of the unlensed DSFGs of Chapman et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib19\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib19\">2005</a>) is &lt;15%.</p><p>The lensed samples appear to recover the \"true\" unlensed size distribution in spite of the bias discussed above. This seems to indicate one of two possibilities. First, it may be that neither the lensed nor unlensed samples are sufficiently complete for differences to be noticeable. The lensed samples effectively select sources based on the product of intrinsic flux density and magnification, while the unlensed samples would not measure the true size distribution if faint sources are preferentially more extended, precluding size measurements from the current ALMA data. Alternatively, the underlying DSFG size distribution may lack sufficient dynamic range for the size bias to become noticeable without a very large number of sources. The true size distribution may have few objects at both very small and very large sizes, making the magnification bias unimportant. Both scenarios are testable from deeper observations of a larger sample of unlensed sources.</p></div><h3 id=\"apjaa2662s5-3\" name=\"apjaa2662s5-3\">5.3.\u00a0Constraining the Dust Opacity</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>The size information we have determined affords us additional constraints on other fitted parameters which would be difficult to determine from unresolved observations. One of the most common fitting functions used to describe the dust emission of galaxies is the \"modified blackbody\" function,</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjaa2662eqn1\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662eqn1.gif\" alt=\"Equation (1)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&{S}_{{\\nu }_{r}}=\\displaystyle \\frac{{{\\rm{\\Omega }}}_{\\mathrm{source}}}{{(1+{z}_{S})}^{3}}({B}_{{\\nu }_{r}}({T}_{{\\rm{dust}}})-{B}_{{\\nu }_{r}}({T}_{\\mathrm{CMB}}))(1-{e}^{-{\\tau }_{{\\nu }_{r}}}),\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t1\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>where <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn84.gif\" alt=\"${B}_{{\\nu }_{r}}(T)$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{B}_{{\\nu }_{r}}(T)</script></span></span> is the Planck function evaluated at rest-frame frequency <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn85.gif\" alt=\"${\\nu }_{r}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\nu }_{r}</script></span></span> and temperature <em>T</em>. This blackbody is \"modified\" by the dust optical depth term, and the overall normalization of the SED is related to the intrinsic source solid angle <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn86.gif\" alt=\"${{\\rm{\\Omega }}}_{\\mathrm{source}}=\\pi {r}_{\\mathrm{eff}}^{2}/{D}_{A}^{2}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{{\\rm{\\Omega }}}_{\\mathrm{source}}=\\pi {r}_{\\mathrm{eff}}^{2}/{D}_{A}^{2}</script></span></span>. At long wavelengths, the dust optical depth can be parameterized as a power law in frequency (e.g., Draine <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib26\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib26\">2006</a>), with <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn87.gif\" alt=\"${\\tau }_{\\nu }={(\\nu /{\\nu }_{0})}^{\\beta }={({\\lambda }_{0}/\\lambda )}^{\\beta }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\tau }_{\\nu }={(\\nu /{\\nu }_{0})}^{\\beta }={({\\lambda }_{0}/\\lambda )}^{\\beta }</script></span></span>, and the optical depth reaching unity at wavelength <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn88.gif\" alt=\"${\\lambda }_{0}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\lambda }_{0}</script></span></span>. The value of <em>\u03b2</em> governs the slope of the Rayleigh\u2013Jeans tail of the dust emission, while the combination of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn89.gif\" alt=\"${T}_{{\\rm{dust}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{T}_{{\\rm{dust}}}</script></span></span>\u00a0and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn90.gif\" alt=\"${\\lambda }_{0}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\lambda }_{0}</script></span></span>\u00a0governs the peak wavelength and width of the peak of the dust emission. The value of <em>\u03b2</em> is generally in the range 1.5\u20132, while the value of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn91.gif\" alt=\"${\\lambda }_{0}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\lambda }_{0}</script></span></span>\u00a0is commonly assumed to be 100\u2013200 <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn92.gif\" alt=\"$\\mu {\\rm{m}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mu {\\rm{m}}</script></span></span> (3\u20131.5 THz; e.g., Blain et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib8\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib8\">2003</a>; Casey et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib18\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib18\">2014</a>).</p><p>For sources without size measurements, the source solid angle is unknown, in addition to the other parameters which control the shape of the dust SED. Even with sizes derived from the lens models, we are forced to assume a single dust temperature and value of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn93.gif\" alt=\"${\\lambda }_{0}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\lambda }_{0}</script></span></span>\u00a0averaged over the source for each object. Improvements on this scenario require spatially resolved continuum measurements at several widely spaced frequencies, especially those which straddle the SED peak. While this may one day be possible, at present we assume that the source emission is uniform, mirroring the assumptions which must be made with unresolved photometry.</p><p>The spatially unresolved long-wavelength SED alone is usually insufficient to constrain the value of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn94.gif\" alt=\"${\\lambda }_{0}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\lambda }_{0}</script></span></span>, as degeneracies with the other parameters (particularly the dust temperature <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn95.gif\" alt=\"${T}_{{\\rm{dust}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{T}_{{\\rm{dust}}}</script></span></span>) allow for good matches to the data for a wide range of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn96.gif\" alt=\"${\\lambda }_{0}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\lambda }_{0}</script></span></span>. The inferred <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn97.gif\" alt=\"${T}_{{\\rm{dust}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{T}_{{\\rm{dust}}}</script></span></span>, in turn, has a large effect on other inferred quantities, such as the total dust mass (e.g., Casey <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib16\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib16\">2012</a>). Our new knowledge of the intrinsic size of the SPT DSFGs offers an alternative avenue for constraining an effective <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn98.gif\" alt=\"${\\lambda }_{0}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\lambda }_{0}</script></span></span>. For those sources with spectroscopic redshifts, we fit the photometry at rest wavelengths <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn99.gif\" alt=\"$\\gt 50$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\gt 50</script></span></span> <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn100.gif\" alt=\"$\\mu {\\rm{m}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mu {\\rm{m}}</script></span></span> with the modified blackbody function given above, assuming <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn101.gif\" alt=\"$\\beta =2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\beta =2</script></span></span> and allowing <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn102.gif\" alt=\"${\\lambda }_{0}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\lambda }_{0}</script></span></span>\u00a0to be a free parameter, although allowing <em>\u03b2</em> as a free parameter does not alter our results. The cutoff at short wavelengths is used because neither the modified blackbody function nor our lens models are expected to capture the emission from hot dust which dominates the short-wavelength side of the SED. This assumption ignores any possible contribution of a hot dust component to the long-wavelength photometry, but <em>Herschel</em>/PACS photometry indicates that this component is negligible at the relevant wavelengths (M. Strandet et al. 2016, in preparation). We have verified that neither a hot dust component nor a short-wavelength power law significantly affect our conclusions.</p><p>We perform the fitting described using the source photometry in Wei\u00df et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib80\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib80\">2013</a>), Strandet et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib71\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib71\">2016</a>), and an MCMC fitting routine. The free parameters are the SED normalization (which stands in for the source solid angle at wavelengths without size measurements; see below), <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn103.gif\" alt=\"${T}_{{\\rm{dust}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{T}_{{\\rm{dust}}}</script></span></span>, and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn104.gif\" alt=\"${\\lambda }_{0}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\lambda }_{0}</script></span></span>. At each MCMC step, we calculate the log-likelihood of producing the spatially unresolved continuum measurements given the proposed combination of parameters, and add to this the log-likelihood of the proposed <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn105.gif\" alt=\"${T}_{{\\rm{dust}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{T}_{{\\rm{dust}}}</script></span></span>\u00a0and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn106.gif\" alt=\"${\\lambda }_{0}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\lambda }_{0}</script></span></span>\u00a0reproducing the intrinsic source flux density determined from the lens models, after marginalizing over the uncertainty in source size. The reason the contributions from the spatially unresolved and resolved measurements must be calculated separately is that, as shown in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaa2662f4\">4</a>, there is a median 10% offset and large scatter between the total flux density measured in our (resolved) ALMA images compared to the (unresolved) LABOCA images at the same wavelength; presumably this scatter would also be present if we resolved the sources at all other wavelengths. In order to avoid biases introduced by this scatter, we use the exact form in Equation (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"eqnref\" href=\"#apjaa2662eqn1\">1</a>) at observed-frame 870 <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn107.gif\" alt=\"$\\mu {\\rm{m}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mu {\\rm{m}}</script></span></span>\u00a0only, and allow a normalization at other wavelengths. This normalization effectively allows us to match flux captured by the large single-dish beams (primarily from galaxies associated with the foreground lensing haloes; Welikala et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib81\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib81\">2016</a>) not included in the lens modeling, as well as general measurement and calibration errors. We have verified that this method does not give unphysical results, and that the inclusion of the lens model sizes merely shrinks the allowable parameter space without driving the solutions to otherwise unfavored values.</p><p>The results of this fitting are shown in the left panel of Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaa2662f6\">6</a>. We find a median value of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn108.gif\" alt=\"${\\lambda }_{0}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\lambda }_{0}</script></span></span> = 140 \u00b1 40 <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn109.gif\" alt=\"$\\mu {\\rm{m}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mu {\\rm{m}}</script></span></span>, which is somewhat larger than the canonically assumed value of 100 <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn110.gif\" alt=\"$\\mu {\\rm{m}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mu {\\rm{m}}</script></span></span>\u00a0(e.g., Greve et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib33\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib33\">2012</a>). Moreover, as previously mentioned, this wavelength is correlated with the inferred dust temperature. Fitting a line to the points shown in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaa2662f6\">6</a> using orthogonal distance regression (marginalizing over the probability of points being outliers; e.g., Hogg et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib41\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib41\">2010</a>) yields</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjaa2662eqn2\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662eqn2.gif\" alt=\"Equation (2)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&{\\lambda }_{0}=(3.0\\pm 0.7)\\times ({T}_{{\\rm{dust}}}-40)+(118\\pm 12)\\,\\mu {\\rm{m}}.\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t2\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>Using this relation provides a better alternative to assuming a single value for <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn111.gif\" alt=\"${\\lambda }_{0}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\lambda }_{0}</script></span></span>\u00a0when the available photometry cannot constrain both <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn112.gif\" alt=\"${\\lambda }_{0}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\lambda }_{0}</script></span></span>\u00a0and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn113.gif\" alt=\"${T}_{{\\rm{dust}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{T}_{{\\rm{dust}}}</script></span></span>\u2014this relation can be easily inserted into likelihood functions when fitting the dust SED. This correlation may manifest in part from the relationship between star formation and molecular gas\u2014at a simplistic level, the star formation rate of dusty galaxies is related to <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn114.gif\" alt=\"${L}_{{\\rm{FIR}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{L}_{{\\rm{FIR}}}</script></span></span>, which in turn is related to <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn115.gif\" alt=\"${T}_{{\\rm{dust}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{T}_{{\\rm{dust}}}</script></span></span>; meanwhile, the gas mass is related to the dust mass, which, as we discuss further below, is related to the dust emissivity encapsulated in <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn116.gif\" alt=\"${\\lambda }_{0}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\lambda }_{0}</script></span></span>.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apjaa2662f6\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjaa2662f6\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662f6_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 6.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 6.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662f6_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 6.</strong>\u00a0Left: correlation between the inferred dust temperature and <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn117.gif\" alt=\"${\\lambda }_{0}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\lambda }_{0}</script></span></span>, the wavelength where the dust optical depth is unity, derived from a joint fit to the FIR photometry and the source properties inferred from the lens models for sources with spectroscopic source redshifts. The solid line and gray region indicate the relation in Equation (<a class=\"eqnref\" href=\"#apjaa2662eqn2\">2</a>) and its associated 68% credibility interval, respectively. The histogram of the inferred values of <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn118.gif\" alt=\"${\\lambda }_{0}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\lambda }_{0}</script></span></span>\u00a0is also shown. The median and standard deviation for the SPT DSFGs is 140 \u00b1 40 <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn119.gif\" alt=\"$\\mu {\\rm{m}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mu {\\rm{m}}</script></span></span>. Right: ratio of the dust mass inferred by allowing <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn120.gif\" alt=\"${\\lambda }_{0}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\lambda }_{0}</script></span></span>\u00a0to be a free parameter in the joint fit of the SED and derived source properties over the dust mass inferred by fixing <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn121.gif\" alt=\"${\\lambda }_{0}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\lambda }_{0}</script></span></span>\u00a0to 100 <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn122.gif\" alt=\"$\\mu {\\rm{m}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mu {\\rm{m}}</script></span></span>. Fixing <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn123.gif\" alt=\"${\\lambda }_{0}=100$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\lambda }_{0}=100</script></span></span> <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn124.gif\" alt=\"$\\mu {\\rm{m}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mu {\\rm{m}}</script></span></span> over-predicts the dust mass by more than a factor of 2 for the sources with the highest dust temperatures.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apjaa2662f6\" href=\"/0004-637X/826/2/112/downloadFigure/figure/apjaa2662f6\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apjaa2662f6\" href=\"/0004-637X/826/2/112/downloadHRFigure/figure/apjaa2662f6\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><p>The impact of this correlation has little effect on the integrated <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn125.gif\" alt=\"${L}_{{\\rm{FIR}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{L}_{{\\rm{FIR}}}</script></span></span>. This is as expected, since our photometric coverage fully samples the SED peak. The dust mass <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn126.gif\" alt=\"${M}_{{\\rm{dust}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{M}_{{\\rm{dust}}}</script></span></span>, on the other hand, is strongly influenced. In the optically thin limit, <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn127.gif\" alt=\"${M}_{{\\rm{dust}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{M}_{{\\rm{dust}}}</script></span></span>\u00a0is related to the source flux density and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn128.gif\" alt=\"${T}_{{\\rm{dust}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{T}_{{\\rm{dust}}}</script></span></span>\u00a0via</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjaa2662eqn3\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662eqn3.gif\" alt=\"Equation (3)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&{M}_{{\\rm{dust}}}=\\displaystyle \\frac{{S}_{{\\nu }_{\\mathrm{obs}}}{D}_{L}^{2}}{{\\kappa }_{{\\nu }_{r}}(1+{z}_{S})({B}_{{\\nu }_{r}}({T}_{{\\rm{dust}}})-{B}_{{\\nu }_{r}}({T}_{\\mathrm{CMB}}))},\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t3\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>(Greve et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib33\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib33\">2012</a>), where <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn129.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\nu }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\nu }</script></span></span> is the dust mass absorption coefficient. At present, we are concerned only with the relative difference in the dust mass determined under various assumptions, and so the form and normalization of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn130.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\nu }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\nu }</script></span></span> are irrelevant (as it is related to the source flux density at one frequency and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn131.gif\" alt=\"${T}_{{\\rm{dust}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{T}_{{\\rm{dust}}}</script></span></span>). The right-hand panel of Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaa2662f6\">6</a> shows the ratio of the dust mass determined through our SED fitting when leaving <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn132.gif\" alt=\"${\\lambda }_{0}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\lambda }_{0}</script></span></span>\u00a0as a free parameter compared to the dust mass inferred by assuming <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn133.gif\" alt=\"${\\lambda }_{0}=100$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\lambda }_{0}=100</script></span></span> <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn134.gif\" alt=\"$\\mu {\\rm{m}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mu {\\rm{m}}</script></span></span>, effected through the changes in the fitted <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn135.gif\" alt=\"${T}_{{\\rm{dust}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{T}_{{\\rm{dust}}}</script></span></span>. A similar range of inferred dust masses are seen for other assumed values, although the range of temperatures with reasonable agreement shifts higher for higher <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn136.gif\" alt=\"${\\lambda }_{0}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\lambda }_{0}</script></span></span>. For dust temperatures <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn137.gif\" alt=\"$\\lesssim 45$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\lesssim 45</script></span></span> K, the difference is relatively small. However, as dust temperature increases, the dust mass is increasingly over-predicted under the assumption that <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn138.gif\" alt=\"${\\lambda }_{0}=100$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\lambda }_{0}=100</script></span></span> <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn139.gif\" alt=\"$\\mu {\\rm{m}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mu {\\rm{m}}</script></span></span>, reaching more than a factor of 2 for the hottest sources. A similar result, ignoring the dust optical depth and instead framed in terms of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn140.gif\" alt=\"${T}_{{\\rm{dust}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{T}_{{\\rm{dust}}}</script></span></span>, was obtained by Magdis et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib50\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib50\">2012</a>), who showed that single-temperature fits underestimated <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn141.gif\" alt=\"${M}_{{\\rm{dust}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{M}_{{\\rm{dust}}}</script></span></span>\u00a0compared to more complex models. This demonstrates that the assumption of a single, constant value of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn142.gif\" alt=\"${\\lambda }_{0}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\lambda }_{0}</script></span></span>\u00a0can cause a severe distortion in other derived quantities, especially those which rely on <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn143.gif\" alt=\"${T}_{{\\rm{dust}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{T}_{{\\rm{dust}}}</script></span></span>.</p></div><h3 id=\"apjaa2662s5-4\" name=\"apjaa2662s5-4\">5.4.\u00a0Revisiting the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]/FIR Ratio</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>The 158 <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn144.gif\" alt=\"$\\mu {\\rm{m}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mu {\\rm{m}}</script></span></span> [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line has long been known as a powerful coolant of the ISM (e.g., Crawford et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib20\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib20\">1986</a>), radiating about 0.1%\u20131% of the total IR luminosity (e.g., Stacey et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib69\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib69\">1991</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib70\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib70\">2010</a>). Unfortunately, [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] can be emitted by gas under a wide variety of conditions, which makes its physical interpretation challenging.</p><p>One challenge in interpreting [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] manifests as the \"[C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] deficit,\" in which the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]/<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn145.gif\" alt=\"${L}_{{\\rm{FIR}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{L}_{{\\rm{FIR}}}</script></span></span>\u00a0ratio can fall rapidly for <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn146.gif\" alt=\"${L}_{{\\rm{FIR}}}\\,\\gtrsim {10}^{11}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{L}_{{\\rm{FIR}}}\\,\\gtrsim {10}^{11}</script></span></span> <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn147.gif\" alt=\"${L}_{\\odot }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{L}_{\\odot }</script></span></span>(e.g., Malhotra et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib51\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib51\">1997</a>; Luhman et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib48\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib48\">1998</a>; Graci\u00e1-Carpio et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib32\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib32\">2011</a>). A variety of physical mechanisms for this deficit have been proposed, including active galactic nucleus (AGN) contributions to <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn148.gif\" alt=\"${L}_{{\\rm{FIR}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{L}_{{\\rm{FIR}}}</script></span></span>(e.g., Sargsyan et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib61\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib61\">2012</a>), increased ionization parameter (e.g., Malhotra et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib52\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib52\">2001</a>; Graci\u00e1-Carpio et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib32\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib32\">2011</a>), collisional de-excitation of [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] (Appleton et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib2\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib2\">2013</a>), and differences in emitting column (Goicoechea et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib31\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib31\">2015</a>). The [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] emission of a sample of 20 SPT DSFGs was studied in detail by Gullberg et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib34\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib34\">2015</a>), who noted that nearly saturated [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] emission (via, e.g., excitation or optical depth effects) could cause much of the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]/<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn149.gif\" alt=\"${L}_{{\\rm{FIR}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{L}_{{\\rm{FIR}}}</script></span></span>variation to be controlled by variations in <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn150.gif\" alt=\"${L}_{{\\rm{FIR}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{L}_{{\\rm{FIR}}}</script></span></span>\u00a0alone. This is tentatively supported by photodissociation models which attempt to simultaneously explain both the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] and CO(1\u20130) emission.</p><p>In their studies of a large sample of local IR-luminous galaxies from the Great Observatories All-Sky LIRG Survey (GOALS), D\u00edaz-Santos et al.
