A variety of physical mechanisms for this deficit have been proposed, including active galactic nucleus (AGN) contributions to <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn148.gif\" alt=\"${L}_{{\\rm{FIR}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{L}_{{\\rm{FIR}}}</script></span></span>(e.g., Sargsyan et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib61\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib61\">2012</a>), increased ionization parameter (e.g., Malhotra et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib52\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib52\">2001</a>; Graci\u00e1-Carpio et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib32\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib32\">2011</a>), collisional de-excitation of [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] (Appleton et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib2\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib2\">2013</a>), and differences in emitting column (Goicoechea et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib31\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib31\">2015</a>). The [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] emission of a sample of 20 SPT DSFGs was studied in detail by Gullberg et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib34\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib34\">2015</a>), who noted that nearly saturated [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] emission (via, e.g., excitation or optical depth effects) could cause much of the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]/<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn149.gif\" alt=\"${L}_{{\\rm{FIR}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{L}_{{\\rm{FIR}}}</script></span></span>variation to be controlled by variations in <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn150.gif\" alt=\"${L}_{{\\rm{FIR}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{L}_{{\\rm{FIR}}}</script></span></span>\u00a0alone. This is tentatively supported by photodissociation models which attempt to simultaneously explain both the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] and CO(1\u20130) emission.</p><p>In their studies of a large sample of local IR-luminous galaxies from the Great Observatories All-Sky LIRG Survey (GOALS), D\u00edaz-Santos et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib24\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib24\">2013</a>) find that the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]/<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn151.gif\" alt=\"${L}_{{\\rm{FIR}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{L}_{{\\rm{FIR}}}</script></span></span>\u00a0ratio is also correlated with the FIR luminosity surface density <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn152.gif\" alt=\"${{\\rm{\\Sigma }}}_{{\\rm{FIR}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{{\\rm{\\Sigma }}}_{{\\rm{FIR}}}</script></span></span>. This correlation held for both purely star-forming galaxies as well as objects with significant AGN activity (although many of the AGN-dominated sources were spatially unresolved, resulting in lower limits on <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn153.gif\" alt=\"${{\\rm{\\Sigma }}}_{{\\rm{FIR}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{{\\rm{\\Sigma }}}_{{\\rm{FIR}}}</script></span></span>). A similar result was obtained for galaxies at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn154.gif\" alt=\"$z\\lt 0.2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\lt 0.2</script></span></span> by Ibar et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib43\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib43\">2015</a>), who additionally noted that the spiral galaxies in their sample had higher [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]/<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn155.gif\" alt=\"${L}_{{\\rm{FIR}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{L}_{{\\rm{FIR}}}</script></span></span>\u00a0ratios than irregular and elliptical galaxies. Using our new measurements of the size of the dust continuum emitting regions of the SPT DSFGs, and drawing on a compilation of high-redshift objects from the literature, we can extend this work two orders of magnitude higher in <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn156.gif\" alt=\"${{\\rm{\\Sigma }}}_{{\\rm{FIR}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{{\\rm{\\Sigma }}}_{{\\rm{FIR}}}</script></span></span>. The result is shown in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaa2662f7\">7</a>. We have re-fit the photometry of all sources to ensure a uniform determination of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn157.gif\" alt=\"${L}_{{\\rm{FIR}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{L}_{{\\rm{FIR}}}</script></span></span>.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apjaa2662f7\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjaa2662f7\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662f7_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 7.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 7.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662f7_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 7.</strong>\u00a0[C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]/FIR luminosity ratio as a function of <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn158.gif\" alt=\"${{\\rm{\\Sigma }}}_{{\\rm{FIR}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{{\\rm{\\Sigma }}}_{{\\rm{FIR}}}</script></span></span>for low-redshift, star-forming sources with a resolved mid-IR size from the GOALS survey (D\u00edaz-Santos et al. <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib24\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib24\">2013</a>), a collection of high-redshift sources from the literature, and the SPT DSFGs (Gullberg et al. <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib34\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib34\">2015</a>). The remarkably tight relation (dashed line) noted by D\u00edaz-Santos et al. (<a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib24\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib24\">2013</a>) continues for at least another two orders of magnitude. A typical uncertainty for the GOALS objects is shown as a black cross. The high-redshift objects are drawn from Walter et al. (<a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib77\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib77\">2009</a>), Carniani et al. (<a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib15\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib15\">2013</a>), Riechers et al. (<a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib58\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib58\">2013</a>), Wang et al. (<a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib78\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib78\">2013</a>), De Breuck et al. (<a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib22\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib22\">2014</a>), Neri et al. (<a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib56\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib56\">2014</a>), Riechers et al. (<a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib59\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib59\">2014</a>), Yun et al. (<a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib82\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib82\">2015</a>), D\u00edaz-Santos et al. (<a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib25\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib25\">2016</a>), and Oteo et al. (<a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib57\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib57\">2016</a>). Note that we have re-fit the photometry of all objects in a consistent manner, as described in Gullberg et al. (<a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib34\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib34\">2015</a>).</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apjaa2662f7\" href=\"/0004-637X/826/2/112/downloadFigure/figure/apjaa2662f7\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apjaa2662f7\" href=\"/0004-637X/826/2/112/downloadHRFigure/figure/apjaa2662f7\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><p>The dashed line in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaa2662f7\">7</a> represents the best-fit relation determined by D\u00edaz-Santos et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib24\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib24\">2013</a>). We have shifted their relation vertically to match our re-determination of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn159.gif\" alt=\"${L}_{{\\rm{FIR}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{L}_{{\\rm{FIR}}}</script></span></span>, but the slope is exactly as determined by D\u00edaz-Santos et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib24\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib24\">2013</a>), i.e., [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn160.gif\" alt=\"$/{L}_{{\\rm{FIR}}}\\,\\propto \\,{{\\rm{\\Sigma }}}_{{\\rm{FIR}}}^{-0.35}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">/{L}_{{\\rm{FIR}}}\\,\\propto \\,{{\\rm{\\Sigma }}}_{{\\rm{FIR}}}^{-0.35}</script></span></span>. The decline continues unabated another two orders of magnitude beyond the limits of the GOALS survey, to at least <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn161.gif\" alt=\"${{\\rm{\\Sigma }}}_{{\\rm{FIR}}}\\sim {10}^{13}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{{\\rm{\\Sigma }}}_{{\\rm{FIR}}}\\sim {10}^{13}</script></span></span> <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn162.gif\" alt=\"${L}_{\\odot }\\,{\\mathrm{kpc}}^{-2}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{L}_{\\odot }\\,{\\mathrm{kpc}}^{-2}</script></span></span>. This lends further support to the claim that the compactness of the IR-emitting region drives the relationship between [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn163.gif\" alt=\"${L}_{{\\rm{FIR}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{L}_{{\\rm{FIR}}}</script></span></span>. A similar correlation can be seen by comparing the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]/<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn164.gif\" alt=\"${L}_{{\\rm{FIR}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{L}_{{\\rm{FIR}}}</script></span></span>\u00a0ratio with the dust temperature <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn165.gif\" alt=\"${T}_{{\\rm{dust}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{T}_{{\\rm{dust}}}</script></span></span>, since, to first order, <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn166.gif\" alt=\"${{\\rm{\\Sigma }}}_{{\\rm{FIR}}}\\propto {L}_{{\\rm{FIR}}}/{r}_{\\mathrm{eff}}^{2}\\propto {T}_{{\\rm{dust}}}^{4}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{{\\rm{\\Sigma }}}_{{\\rm{FIR}}}\\propto {L}_{{\\rm{FIR}}}/{r}_{\\mathrm{eff}}^{2}\\propto {T}_{{\\rm{dust}}}^{4}</script></span></span>. This correlation was first shown by Malhotra et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib51\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib51\">1997</a>) and further explored by Gullberg et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib34\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib34\">2015</a>), who determined that most of the variation could indeed by explained by the Stefan\u2013Boltzmann law, with a small residual dependence on <em>T</em><sub>dust</sub>. Formulating the correlation in terms of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn167.gif\" alt=\"${{\\rm{\\Sigma }}}_{{\\rm{FIR}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{{\\rm{\\Sigma }}}_{{\\rm{FIR}}}</script></span></span>\u00a0itself, however, leads to a dispersion approximately a factor of 2 smaller than formulating it in terms of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn168.gif\" alt=\"${T}_{{\\rm{dust}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{T}_{{\\rm{dust}}}</script></span></span>\u00a0(D\u00edaz-Santos et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib24\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib24\">2013</a>). While the nature of the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] emission is still uncertain, it is clear that the compactness of the IR-emitting region plays a vital role in determining the coupling of the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]-emitting gas with the warm dust.</p></div></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apjaa2662s6\" name=\"apjaa2662s6\">6.\u00a0CONCLUSIONS</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>We have used ALMA 870 <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn169.gif\" alt=\"$\\mu {\\rm{m}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mu {\\rm{m}}</script></span></span>\u00a0observations of 47 gravitationally lensed DSFGs to model the effects of gravitational lensing. Using a visibility-based modeling routine which accounts for several calibration uncertainties, we can recover the intrinsic properties of the background sources. At least 33 of the sources are confirmed to undergo galaxy-scale strong lensing (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn170.gif\" alt=\"${\\mu }_{870\\mu {\\rm{m}}}\\gt 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\mu }_{870\\mu {\\rm{m}}}\\gt 2</script></span></span>), while the remaining sources are lensed by galaxy clusters, or are weakly lensed or unlensed (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn171.gif\" alt=\"${\\mu }_{870\\mu {\\rm{m}}}\\lt 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\mu }_{870\\mu {\\rm{m}}}\\lt 2</script></span></span>). The background sources are magnified by a median factor of 5.5 for all sources, or 6.3 for the strongly lensed subset alone, with a tail that extends to <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn172.gif\" alt=\"${\\mu }_{870\\mu {\\rm{m}}}\\gt 30$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\mu }_{870\\mu {\\rm{m}}}\\gt 30</script></span></span>.</p><p>The sources have a median intrinsic angular FWHM of 0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />28. In spite of a potential size bias of lensed systems, in which compact background sources can be magnified more highly than extended sources, we find no significant differences between the size distributions of existing strongly lensed and unlensed samples of DSFGs. Increasing the number of unlensed sources with spectroscopic redshifts will indicate whether this corresponds to a difference in physical size scale, though this effect is small over the plausible range of redshifts. If the similarity in size distributions is not a chance effect owing to the limited number of sources with size measurements, then we argue that this may indicate that the intrinsic size distribution of DSFGs is sufficiently narrow that the effect of the size bias is not detectable.</p><p>We use the sizes derived from the lens models together with the extensive FIR/submillimeter photometric coverage to constrain <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn173.gif\" alt=\"${\\lambda }_{0}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\lambda }_{0}</script></span></span>, the wavelength where the dust opacity is unity. The size information from the lens models allows us to overcome parameter degeneracies which limit our ability to constrain this wavelength from the SED alone. We find a median transition wavelength of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn174.gif\" alt=\"${\\lambda }_{0}=140\\pm 40$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\lambda }_{0}=140\\pm 40</script></span></span> <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn175.gif\" alt=\"$\\mu {\\rm{m}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mu {\\rm{m}}</script></span></span>, somewhat longer than the generally assumed 100 <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn176.gif\" alt=\"$\\mu {\\rm{m}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mu {\\rm{m}}</script></span></span>. We provide a fitting formula between <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn177.gif\" alt=\"${\\lambda }_{0}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\lambda }_{0}</script></span></span>\u00a0and the dust temperature <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn178.gif\" alt=\"${T}_{{\\rm{dust}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{T}_{{\\rm{dust}}}</script></span></span>\u00a0which can be used for sources without size measurements. We show that assuming a single, fixed value for <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn179.gif\" alt=\"${\\lambda }_{0}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\lambda }_{0}</script></span></span>\u00a0leads to variations of a factor of 2 in the inferred dust mass which can be propagated forward to, e.g., the gas mass under overly simplified assumptions.</p><p>Finally, we make use of our extensive follow-up program targeting the 158 <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn180.gif\" alt=\"$\\mu {\\rm{m}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mu {\\rm{m}}</script></span></span>\u00a0FIR fine structure line of [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]. We show that high-redshift galaxies (over half of them from the SPT DSFG sample) follow the same relationship between [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]/<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn181.gif\" alt=\"${L}_{{\\rm{FIR}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{L}_{{\\rm{FIR}}}</script></span></span>\u00a0and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn182.gif\" alt=\"${{\\rm{\\Sigma }}}_{{\\rm{FIR}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{{\\rm{\\Sigma }}}_{{\\rm{FIR}}}</script></span></span>\u00a0as the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn183.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 0$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 0</script></span></span> IR-luminous galaxies in the <em>Herschel</em> GOALS sample, extending this correlation another two orders of magnitude higher in <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn184.gif\" alt=\"${{\\rm{\\Sigma }}}_{{\\rm{FIR}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{{\\rm{\\Sigma }}}_{{\\rm{FIR}}}</script></span></span>. This agrees with the claim that the controlling parameter in the \"[C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] deficit\" is the compactness of the IR-emitting region, regardless of the dust heating source. Future spatially resolved observations of the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line at high redshifts will indicate whether this global correlation is also present on sub-galactic scales.</p></div> <div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>J.S.S., D.P.M., K.C.L., and J.D.V. acknowledge support from the U.S. National Science Foundation under grant No. AST-1312950 and through award SOSPA2-012 from the NRAO. M.A. acknowledges partial support from FONDECYT through grant 1140099. This material has made use of the El Gato high-performance computer, supported by the US National Science Foundation under grant No. 1228509. This paper makes use of the following ALMA data: ADS/JAO.ALMA #2011.0.00957.S, #2011.0.00958.S, #2012.1.00844.S, and #2012.1.00994.S. ALMA is a partnership of ESO (representing its member states), NSF (USA), and NINS (Japan), together with NRC (Canada), NSC, and ASIAA (Taiwan), in cooperation with the Republic of Chile. The Joint ALMA Observatory is operated by ESO, AUI/NRAO, and NAOJ. The National Radio Astronomy Observatory is a facility of the National Science Foundation operated under cooperative agreement by Associated Universities, Inc. The SPT is supported by the National Science Foundation through grant PLR-1248097, with partial support through PHY-1125897, the Kavli Foundation and the Gordon and Betty Moore Foundation grant GBMF 947. This work makes use of an extensive optical/NIR follow-up campaign, including <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> programs #12659 and #13614, Very Large Telescope programs 085.A-0608, 086.A-0797, 088.A-0902, 090.A-0503, 092.A-0480, 284.A-5029, and 285.A-5034, Gemini Observatory programs GS-2013B-Q-5 and GS-2013A-Q-33, and data gathered with the <em>Magellan</em> Telescopes and the <em>Spitzer Space Telescope</em>. This research has made use of NASA's Astrophysics Data System.</p></div><h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apjaa2662app1\" name=\"apjaa2662app1\">APPENDIX A: NOTES ON THE LENS MODELS OF INDIVIDUAL SOURCES</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p><em>SPT0020-51</em>\u2014This source is lensed by a small group of galaxies, and the source emission can be adequately described by two S\u00e9rsic profiles. Oddly, the brightest, northernmost galaxy seems to have virtually no effect on the lensing geometry. We have verified the astrometry of the images shown in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaa2662f2\">2</a>. It may be that the northern lensing galaxy is at a different redshift from the other two, such that its influence on the overall deflection is small. The complex lensing environment is likely responsible for the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn185.gif\" alt=\"$\\sim 6\\sigma $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\sim 6\\sigma</script></span></span> peak residual structure seen, given the limitations of our relatively simple model.</p><p><em>SPT0027-50</em>\u2014This source presents a complex lensing environment. We find that modeling three of the lensing galaxies and an external shear produces a model which describes the data reasonably well.</p><p><em>SPT0103-45</em>\u2014The lens galaxy in this system appears to have a tidal feature or spiral arm outside of the lensed emission seen by ALMA. Two S\u00e9rsic components are required to model the emission. Interestingly, the CO(3\u20132) line observed by Wei\u00df et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib80\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib80\">2013</a>) also shows an asymmetric double-peaked profile.</p><p><em>SPT0109-47</em>\u2014This source is reasonably well fit by a model accounting for three lensing galaxies. Even still, the flux ratios of the four images are not entirely reproduced by the model. This likely indicates that the complexities of the lensing environment are not fully accounted for by the model.</p><p><em>SPT0113-46</em>\u2014This source is also lensed by a group of galaxies. We model the three closest galaxies, which is sufficient to reproduce the observed emission. The best-fit model with the positions of all three galaxies as free parameters shows some tension with the locations of the galaxies in our <em>HST</em> imaging. This may be due to the gravitational potential in which the galaxies reside or the effects of other group members we have not modeled. Fixing the relative positions of the galaxies to their separations in the <em>HST</em> imaging results in significantly higher residuals but changes the inferred source size and magnification by <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn186.gif\" alt=\"$\\lesssim 10$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\lesssim 10</script></span></span>%. Since the effect on these quantities of greatest interest is small, we show the best-fit model with the positions of all three galaxies as free parameters.</p><p><em>SPT0125-47</em>\u2014This source is detected with a peak significance of nearly 150, and required three source-plane components to model the data. Even this model leaves <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn187.gif\" alt=\"$\\sim 6\\sigma $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\sim 6\\sigma</script></span></span> residuals, which may indicate that an SIE is an imperfect representation of the lens mass profile. The structure of the residuals indicates that additional angular structure in the lens in the form of multipoles may be necessary to accurately capture the complexity of the lens mass profile.</p><p><em>SPT0125-50</em>\u2014We model this source using two S\u00e9rsic components. The faint counterimage to the southwest of the lens is only moderately well reproduced by this model, which may indicate further structure in the source and/or lens planes.</p><p><em>SPT0128-51</em>\u2014This source appears to consist of two components, at best mildly lensed by a galaxy ~7<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />5 to the north. We estimate the magnification experienced by these two components by assuming the lens galaxy has an Einstein radius of 0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />75 approximately the median of all the lens galaxies in our sample. Under this assumption, the eastern and western components have magnifications of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn188.gif\" alt=\"${\\mu }_{870\\mu {\\rm{m}}}=1.16$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\mu }_{870\\mu {\\rm{m}}}=1.16</script></span></span> and 1.20, respectively.</p><p><em>SPT0202-61</em>\u2014This source is well represented by two source-plane components. We also detect a second source ~7'' south of the main lens. This second component has <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn189.gif\" alt=\"${S}_{870\\mu {\\rm{m}}}=4.1\\pm 0.4$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{S}_{870\\mu {\\rm{m}}}=4.1\\pm 0.4</script></span></span> mJy. As we do not know the redshift(s) of the background sources, it is unclear whether they are physically related or simply a chance projection.</p><p><em>SPT0243-49</em>\u2014This is the highest-redshift source we consider here, at <em>z</em> = 5.70. The lens appears highly elongated, with a possible tidal tail extending east.</p><p><em>SPT0245-63</em>\u2014This source appears to be a rare case in which the emission we detect is associated with a large foreground galaxy. The 870 <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn190.gif\" alt=\"$\\mu {\\rm{m}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mu {\\rm{m}}</script></span></span>\u00a0emission is not obviously consistent with lensing, even when only visibilities on baselines &gt;100 k<em>\u03bb</em> are considered. We consider a lensing origin of the 870 <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn191.gif\" alt=\"$\\mu {\\rm{m}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mu {\\rm{m}}</script></span></span>\u00a0emission unlikely, as the implied lens mass is implausibly small (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn192.gif\" alt=\"$\\lt {10}^{10}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\lt {10}^{10}</script></span></span> <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn193.gif\" alt=\"${M}_{\\odot }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{M}_{\\odot }</script></span></span>\u00a0for <em>z</em><sub><em>L</em></sub> = 0.3) given the brightness of the putative lens (K-band magnitude 16.3). Additional optical/NIR and millimeter spectroscopy is needed to determine the nature of this source conclusively.</p><p><em>SPT0300-46</em>\u2014This source is well fit by two source-plane components, and the CO(4\u20133) line clearly shows two velocity components (Gullberg et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib34\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib34\">2015</a>). While the source is not clearly resolved into multiple images, imaging the visibilities with baselines &gt;100 k<em>\u03bb</em> clearly shows the arc-like structure reproduced in the best-fit model. The field also includes a 9 mJy source ~8'' west of the lensed source.</p><p><em>SPT0319-47</em>\u2014This source is also moderately resolved at 0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />5 resolution, and is adequately fit by a single S\u00e9rsic component. Imaging the visibilities with baselines &gt;100 k<em>\u03bb</em> confirms that the source splits into two lensed images as predicted by the best-fit model.</p><p><em>SPT0345-47</em>\u2014This source is unambiguously lensed, as we have measured distinct lens and source redshifts. Imaging only baselines &gt;100 k<em>\u03bb</em> confirms that the arc and counterimage structure seen in the best-fit model is correct.</p><p><em>SPT0346-52</em>\u2014This source was one of four resolved at ~1<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />5 resolution and studied by Hezaveh et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib37\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib37\">2013</a>). Combining those data with the higher-resolution observations presented here largely confirms the previous model. The data also favor the existence of an external shear component at an angle roughly in line with the galaxy ~3'' east of the main lens.</p><p><em>SPT0348-62</em>\u2014This object appears to be a collection of several weakly lensed sources. We assume an Einstein radius of 1'' for the galaxy approximately 6'' east of the bulk of the emission. Much of the 870 <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn194.gif\" alt=\"$\\mu {\\rm{m}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mu {\\rm{m}}</script></span></span>\u00a0emission is not well represented by simple Gaussian components, although four elliptical Gaussian components provide an adequate fit. The four components are magnified by factors of 1.16\u20131.26, assuming the Einstein radius above.</p><p><em>SPT0403-58</em>\u2014This source appears to be marginally lensed by the nearby galaxy.</p><p><em>SPT0404-59</em>\u2014This object is the most weakly detected source in this sample, and the images we do detect straddle the ALMA primary beam half-power radius. A single source-plane component represents the data well, although deeper observations will be necessary to place better constraints on the lens and source geometry.</p><p><em>SPT0418-47</em>\u2014This source was also considered by Hezaveh et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib37\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib37\">2013</a>). Our model, which incorporates higher-resolution data available after publication of Hezaveh et al., finds a higher magnification, <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn195.gif\" alt=\"${\\mu }_{870\\mu {\\rm{m}}}=32$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\mu }_{870\\mu {\\rm{m}}}=32</script></span></span>, as the higher-resolution data show a nearly perfect Einstein ring. This source is the most highly magnified galaxy-scale lens in the current sample.</p><p><em>SPT0441-46</em>\u2014This source is well modeled by a single S\u00e9rsic background component.</p><p><em>SPT0452-50</em>\u2014With distinct lens and source redshifts, this source appears to be only mildly lensed by the faint galaxy ~3'' to the south of the ALMA emission. It is the highest-redshift lens with a confirmed redshift in the current sample.</p><p><em>SPT0459-58</em>\u2014This source is marginally resolved into multiple images by ALMA. Imaging those visibilities with baselines &gt;75 k<em>\u03bb</em> confirms that the multiple images seen in the best-fit model are real.</p><p><em>SPT0459-59</em>\u2014In addition to a strongly lensed component, this source also contains a fainter source, weakly lensed by a factor of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn196.gif\" alt=\"${\\mu }_{870\\mu {\\rm{m}}}=1.5$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\mu }_{870\\mu {\\rm{m}}}=1.5</script></span></span>. Imaging only the visibilities on baselines &gt;75 k<em>\u03bb</em> makes the lensed nature of the emission more readily apparent.</p><p><em>SPT0529-54</em>\u2014This source was also studied by Hezaveh et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib37\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib37\">2013</a>), and is the only source for which the model which incorporates the higher-resolution data now available to us significantly differs from the previous model. The model presented here allows ellipticity in the background source, which entirely accounts for the model differences. That is, fitting an elliptical component to the data available at the time of publication of Hezaveh et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib37\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib37\">2013</a>) recovers the model shown here, while fitting a circularly symmetric Gaussian source to the data from both array configurations recovers the model shown in Hezaveh et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib37\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib37\">2013</a>). The higher-resolution data now available clearly resolve the source into four images, which was not apparent in the lower-resolution data. The full data strongly prefer the elliptical source-plane model over a circularly symmetric model.</p><p><em>SPT0532-50</em>\u2014This source shows a clear hole in the center of a ring of emission, and is well fit by a single source-plane component.</p><p><em>SPT0538-50</em>\u2014This source has been the subject of detailed studies by Bothwell et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib10\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib10\">2013</a>) and Spilker et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib67\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib67\">2015</a>), and was included in the sample of Hezaveh et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib37\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib37\">2013</a>). Our model confirms the need for two source-plane components, which Spilker et al. associate with the two velocity components seen in observations of CO(1\u20130) and CO(3\u20132).</p><p><em>SPT2031-51</em>\u2014A single S\u00e9rsic component is sufficient to accurately reproduce the ALMA data.</p><p><em>SPT2048-55</em>\u2014The lens in this system appears to have a tidal feature extending to the west of the galaxy; nevertheless, a single SIE lens and background S\u00e9rsic component fit the data quite well.</p><p><em>SPT2052-56</em>\u2014This source is not point-like at 0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />5 resolution, but appears completely unlensed. A circularly symmetric Gaussian reproduces the data well.</p><p><em>SPT2103-60</em>\u2014This source presents an unusual lensing geometry, caused by the combined effects of the three foreground galaxies. We place loose priors on the locations of the three lensing galaxies but do not require that they have the same relative locations as seen in the VLT/ISAAC image. Remarkably, a single source-plane component adequately reproduces the data.</p><p><em>SPT2132-58</em>\u2014The background source in this system is moderately resolved by ALMA. Imaging only the visibilities with baselines &gt;75 k<em>\u03bb</em> confirms the arc-like structure with faint counterimage predicted by the best-fit model. This source was studied in detail by B\u00e9thermin et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib5\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib5\">2016</a>).</p><p><em>SPT2134-50</em>\u2014A single source-plane component with half-light radius of just ~270 pc is magnified by a factor of 21 in this source.</p><p><em>SPT2146-55</em>\u2014This source is well described by a single SIE lens and background S\u00e9rsic component.</p><p><em>SPT2146-56</em>\u2014This source appears point-like in the ALMA data, and lies on top of a galaxy identified at <em>z</em> = 0.67. The unresolved SED of this source (Strandet et al. 2016, in preparation) is also atypical, showing what appears to be two dust peaks. Whatever the true nature of this source, it does not appear to be a galaxy-scale lensed DSFG.</p><p><em>SPT2147-50</em>\u2014A simple SIE lens and single S\u00e9rsic background component are sufficient to reproduce the ALMA data.</p><p><em>SPT2300-51</em>\u2014No sources were detected at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn197.gif\" alt=\"$\\gt 5\\sigma $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\gt 5\\sigma</script></span></span> significance within the ALMA primary beam half-power radius, and this object was determined to be a spurious detection in the LABOCA follow-up of SPT sources. This source is shown in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaa2662f8\">8</a>. Two potential sources exist at approximately the 38% and 25% primary beam response levels, with nominal significance of 4 and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn198.gif\" alt=\"$6\\sigma $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">6\\sigma</script></span></span>, respectively; we consider both likely to be false. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaa2662f9\"> </a>\n</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apjaa2662f8\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjaa2662f8\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662f8_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 8.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 8.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662f8_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 8.</strong>\u00a0ALMA 870 <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn199.gif\" alt=\"$\\mu {\\rm{m}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mu {\\rm{m}}</script></span></span>\u00a0image of SPT2300-51 (blue contours) overlaid on a VLT/ISAAC K-band image (grayscale), centered on the ALMA phase center. Contours are drawn at 50% and 90% of the image peak value, and the ALMA primary beam half-power radius is indicated with a dotted line. The synthesized beam is indicated in the lower left corner. The two highest peaks in the image are located at approximately 38% and 25% of the peak primary beam response, and both are likely false.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apjaa2662f8\" href=\"/0004-637X/826/2/112/downloadFigure/figure/apjaa2662f8\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apjaa2662f8\" href=\"/0004-637X/826/2/112/downloadHRFigure/figure/apjaa2662f8\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apjaa2662f9\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjaa2662f9\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662f9_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 9.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 9.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662f9_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 9.</strong>\u00a0ALMA 870 <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn200.gif\" alt=\"$\\mu {\\rm{m}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mu {\\rm{m}}</script></span></span>\u00a0emission (blue contours) overlaid on the <em>HST</em>/WFC3 images (grayscale) for the four cluster-lensed galaxies in the current sample. Contours are drawn at 10%, 50%, and 90% of the peak value, and the ALMA primary beam half-power radius is indicated with a dotted line. The synthesized beam is indicated in the lower left corner. Grayscale images are logarithmically scaled to emphasize the relevant objects detected.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apjaa2662f9\" href=\"/0004-637X/826/2/112/downloadFigure/figure/apjaa2662f9\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apjaa2662f9\" href=\"/0004-637X/826/2/112/downloadHRFigure/figure/apjaa2662f9\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><p><em>SPT2311-54</em>\u2014This source is only marginally resolved by ALMA, but we have measured distinct lens and source redshifts which confirm the lensed nature of this source. Imaging only those visibilities with baselines &gt;150 k<em>\u03bb</em> reveals structure consistent with the best-fit model.</p><p><em>SPT2319-55</em>\u2014This source is well fit by two source-plane components.</p><p><em>SPT2340-59</em>\u2014The nature of this source is unclear. While the 870 <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn201.gif\" alt=\"$\\mu {\\rm{m}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mu {\\rm{m}}</script></span></span>\u00a0data appear to show a standard doubly imaged background source, the two images were also spatially resolved in an ALMA 3 mm project to determine its redshift. These data show a weak line, identified as CO(4\u20133), in the eastern component only (Strandet et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib71\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib71\">2016</a>). This suggests the two images seen at 870 <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn202.gif\" alt=\"$\\mu {\\rm{m}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mu {\\rm{m}}</script></span></span>\u00a0may in fact be two unlensed or weakly lensed sources at different redshifts. In Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaa2662f2\">2</a>, we show the model assuming the two sources seen by ALMA are lensed images of the same source, in which case the source is magnified by a factor of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn203.gif\" alt=\"${\\mu }_{870\\mu {\\rm{m}}}=4.0$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\mu }_{870\\mu {\\rm{m}}}=4.0</script></span></span> and has <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn204.gif\" alt=\"${S}_{870\\mu {\\rm{m}}}\\,=$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{S}_{870\\mu {\\rm{m}}}\\,=</script></span></span> 9.1 mJy. If, on the other hand, the two images are distinct sources, then we derive their intrinsic properties by fixing the position of the foreground lens galaxy to the location in the VLT/FORS2 image. This yields <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn205.gif\" alt=\"${\\mu }_{870\\mu {\\rm{m}}}=1.3$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\mu }_{870\\mu {\\rm{m}}}=1.3</script></span></span>, <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn206.gif\" alt=\"${S}_{870\\mu {\\rm{m}}}\\,=$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{S}_{870\\mu {\\rm{m}}}\\,=</script></span></span> 15.2 mJy and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn207.gif\" alt=\"${\\mu }_{870\\mu {\\rm{m}}}=1.7$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\mu }_{870\\mu {\\rm{m}}}=1.7</script></span></span>, <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn208.gif\" alt=\"${S}_{870\\mu {\\rm{m}}}\\,=$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{S}_{870\\mu {\\rm{m}}}\\,=</script></span></span> 8.7 mJy for the western and eastern components, respectively.</p><p><em>SPT2349-50</em>\u2014This source is doubly imaged by the foreground lens. Imaging the visibilities on baselines &gt;125 k<em>\u03bb</em> clearly resolves the two lensed images separated by ~0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />5.</p><p><em>SPT2349-56</em>\u2014We detect six sources at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn209.gif\" alt=\"$\\geqslant 5\\sigma $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\geqslant 5\\sigma</script></span></span> significance in this source, none of which appear to be significantly lensed. ALMA 3 mm data (Strandet et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib71\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib71\">2016</a>) resolve the bright northern component from the three more southern components. A line identified as CO(4\u20133) in these data, along with [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] confirmation using APEX, places this source at <em>z</em><sub><em>S</em></sub> = 4.30. It is unclear whether all six components detected at 870 <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn210.gif\" alt=\"$\\mu {\\rm{m}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mu {\\rm{m}}</script></span></span>\u00a0are at the same redshift or whether they represent a chance alignment of sources at different redshifts. Only three of the six components are spatially resolved at the ~0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />5 resolution of these data.</p><p><em>SPT2354-58</em>\u2014This source has the lowest confirmed redshift of any object in the SPT sample, at <em>z</em><sub><em>S</em></sub> = 1.87 (Strandet et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib71\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib71\">2016</a>). Imaging the visibilities with baselines &gt;125 k<em>\u03bb</em> confirms the arc and counterimage predicted by the best-fit model, separated by ~0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />5.</p><p><em>SPT2357-51</em>\u2014This source does not obviously separate into multiple images in the ALMA data, even when imaging only the data on baselines &gt;125 k<em>\u03bb</em>. If the source were unlensed, however, its implied flux density would be <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn211.gif\" alt=\"${S}_{870\\mu {\\rm{m}}}\\sim 40$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{S}_{870\\mu {\\rm{m}}}\\sim 40</script></span></span> mJy, the brightest of any DSFG. Given this and the proximity of foreground galaxies along the line of sight, we consider the lensing hypothesis more probable. The current data are well fit by a single Gaussian component.</p></div><h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apjaa2662app2\" name=\"apjaa2662app2\">APPENDIX B: CLUSTER-LENSED SOURCES</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>In this appendix, we show the ALMA images of the four sources which appear to be lensed by large groups or clusters of galaxies. These sources are shown in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaa2662f9\">9</a>. The ALMA data show only single images of the background sources, making lens models impossible to constrain from the limited data available.</p></div></div><!-- End article full text -->\n<!-- Start Footnotes -->\n\t<!-- End Footnotes -->\t\n<!-- Start References List -->\n\n<div class=\"reveal-container reveal-closed reveal-plus-icon exp-w-hash references\">\n                <div class=\"big-branded\">\n\n    <div class=\"publication-name\" id=\"wd-pub-name\">\n\t<div class=\"publication-title\" itemprop=\"name\" itemid=\"periodical\">\n\t\t\t\t<!-- Journal image link tile    <div class=\"partner-logo-alignment\">\n                <!-- Partner logo tile starts -->\n<a href=\"\" class=\"overlay-launch\">\n    <img border=\"0\" <div class=\"overlay-text\">\n            <p>The American Astronomical Society (AAS), established in 1899 and based in Washington, DC, is the major organization of professional astronomers in North America. Its membership of about 7,000 individuals also includes physicists, mathematicians, geologists, engineers, and others whose research and educational interests lie within the broad spectrum of subjects comprising contemporary astronomy. The mission of the AAS is to enhance and share humanity's scientific understanding of the universe.</p> <p><a href=\"https://aas.org/\">https://aas.org/</a></div>\n        <p class=\"ta-c mt-1 mb-2\"><a href=\"\"></a></p>\n    </div>\n</span>\n<!-- Partner logo tile ends -->\n\n<!-- Partner logo tile starts -->\n<a href=\"\" class=\"overlay-launch\">\n    <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/7ebd1b32-0439-11e9-b401-cfe9679c40e3/iop-2016.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The Institute of Physics, find out more\">\n</a>\n<span class=\"overlay-set\">\n    <div class=\"tint-screen\"></div>\n    <div class=\"overlay-panel\">\n        <a title=\"Close\"  class=\"close-icon close-overlay\" tabindex=\"0\" role=\"button\" aria-describedby=\"close-icon-description\"><span class=\"icon-close\"></span></a>\n        <p id=\"close-icon-description\" class=\"offscreen-hidden\">Click here to close this overlay, or press the \"Escape\" key on your keyboard.</p>\n        <div class=\"overlay-img\">\n            <a href=\"\">\n                <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/7ebd1b32-0439-11e9-b401-cfe9679c40e3/iop-2016.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The Institute of Physics, find out more\">\n            </a>\n        </div>\n        <div class=\"overlay-text\">\n            <p>The Institute of Physics (IOP) is a leading scientific society promoting physics and bringing physicists together for the benefit of all. It has a worldwide membership of around 50 000 comprising physicists from all sectors, as well as those with an interest in physics. It works to advance physics research, application and education; and engages with policy makers and the public to develop awareness and understanding of physics. Its publishing company, IOP Publishing, is a world leader in professional scientific communications.</p> <p><a href=\"https://www.iop.org\">https://www.iop.org</a></p></div>\n        <p class=\"ta-c mt-1 mb-2\"><a href=\"\"></a></p>\n    </div>\n</span>\n<!-- Partner logo tile ends -->\n\n<p></p>\n                </div>\n        </div>\n    </div>\n<!-- Branded journal header ends -->\n</div> <!-- end secondary-header -->\n<!-- Secondary header ends --><div class=\"da1-da2\" itemscope=\"\" itemtype=\"http://schema.org/ScholarlyArticle\" id=\"page-content\">\n            <div class=\"da1 ta1 article-head\">\n                <!-- Start Eyebrow block, containing Surtitle and Labels -->\n<div class=\"eyebrow\">\n\t<!-- Start Collection Labels -->\n    <!-- End Collection Labels --> </div>\n<!-- End Eyebrow block -->\n\n<h1 itemprop=\"headline\" class=\"wd-jnl-art-title\">ALMA IMAGING AND GRAVITATIONAL LENS MODELS OF SOUTH POLE TELESCOPE\u2014SELECTED DUSTY, STAR-FORMING GALAXIES AT HIGH REDSHIFTS</h1>\n\n<p class=\"mb-0\">\n\t<span data-authors=\"\">\n\t\t<span itemtype=\"http://schema.org/Person\" itemprop=\"author\" class=\"nowrap\"><span itemprop=\"name\">J. Street, Urbana, IL 61801, USA</p><p class=\"mb-05\"><sup>15</sup>  Department of Physics, Oxford University, Denis Wilkinson Building, Keble Road, Oxford, OX1 3RH, UK</p></div><!-- End Affiliations       <form id=\"alertsForm\" class=\"overlay-panel__form\" method=\"post\" action=\"\" role=\"form\" aria-labelledby=\"alerts-box-title\">\n                <div class=\"overlay-panel__header\">\n                    <div class=\"overlay-panel__logo\"></div>\n                    <span id=\"alerts-box-title\" class=\"replica-h2\">Corridor alerts</span>\n                    <p
