You will need to select a minimum of one corridor.\n                    </p>\n                </div>\n                <div class=\"overlay-panel__container\">\n                    <div class=\"overlay-panel__col\">\n                        <fieldset id=\"alerts-corridors-list\">\n                            <legend id=\"corridors-title\" class=\"overlay-panel__heading replica-h3 mb-05\">Corridors</legend>\n                        </fieldset>\n                    </div>\n                    <div class=\"overlay-panel__col\">\n                        <fieldset id=\"alerts-journals-list\">\n                            <legend id=\"journals-title\" class=\"overlay-panel__heading replica-h3 mb-05\">Journals</legend>\n                        </fieldset>\n                    </div>\n                    <div class=\"boxout-bg-blue-light overlay-panel__extra-info\">\n                        <p>\n                            Please note, The Astrophysical Journal Letters (ApJL) and Research Notes of the AAS (RNAAS)\n                            do not currently use the corridors.\n                        </p>\n                    </div>\n                </div>\n                <div class=\"overlay-panel__footer\">\n                    <div class=\"overlay-panel__inner-footer\">\n                        <input id=\"update-alerts\" type=\"submit\" value=\"Create alert\" class=\"btn btn-default overlay-panel__btn\" role=\"button\">\n                        <div class=\"icon-spinner spinner overlay-panel__loading\"></div>\n                    </div>\n                </div>\n            </form>\n        </div>\n    </div>\n</span>\n<!-- End TOC Subjects Popup -->\n            <p class=\"mb-0\"><a class=\"wd-jnl-email-alert jnl-email-alert--corridors-info\" href=\"https://journals.aas.org/corridors.html\"\n               target=\"_blank\" title=\"Find out more about AAS corridors.\">\n                What are corridors? <span class=\"icon-newtab\">\n            </a></p>\n        </div>\n\n    <!-- End Email Alert -->\n<!-- End Email Alert --><!-- Start Citation Alert Link -->\n                        <p>\n<div class=\"jnl-notifications-wrapper\">\n    <a class=\"wd-jnl-email-alert\" href=\"https://myiopscience.iop.org/signin?origin=a0&return=https%3A%2F%2Fiopscience.iop.org%2Fmyiopscience%2Falerts%2Fsubscribe%3FarticleID%3D0004-637X%2F826%2F2%2F112\"><span\n            class=\"icon-alarm icon-alarm--jhp\"></span>Create citation alert</a>\n</div><!-- End Citation Alert Link -->\n                    </div>\n\t\t</div>\n    </div>\n    <!-- Article information ends -->\n<!-- Start Info top-->\n    <!-- end Info top --><div class=\"article-content\">\n\t<span id=\"articleId\" class=\"hide\">0004-637X/826/2/112</span>\n<!-- Start Abstract -->\n    <h2 id=\"artAbst\" class=\"collapse-blocked\">Abstract</h2>\n        <!-- Start article video abstract -->\n\t<!-- End article video abstract -->\n\t<div class=\"article-text wd-jnl-art-abstract cf\" itemprop=\"description\">\n             <P>The South Pole Telescope has discovered 100 gravitationally lensed, high-redshift, dusty, star-forming galaxies (DSFGs). We present 0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />5 resolution 870 <IMG ALIGN=\"MIDDLE\" alt=\"$\\mu {\\rm{m}}$\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/apjaa2662ieqn1.gif\"></IMG>\u00a0Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array imaging of a sample of 47 DSFGs spanning <IMG ALIGN=\"MIDDLE\" alt=\"$z=1.9\\mbox{--}5.7$\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/apjaa2662ieqn2.gif\"></IMG>, and construct gravitational lens models of these sources. Our visibility-based lens modeling incorporates several sources of residual interferometric calibration uncertainty, allowing us to properly account for noise in the observations. At least 70% of the sources are strongly lensed by foreground galaxies (<IMG ALIGN=\"MIDDLE\" alt=\"${\\mu }_{870\\mu {\\rm{m}}}\\gt 2$\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/apjaa2662ieqn3.gif\"></IMG>), with a median magnification of <IMG ALIGN=\"MIDDLE\" alt=\"${\\mu }_{870\\mu {\\rm{m}}}=6.3$\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/apjaa2662ieqn4.gif\"></IMG>, extending to <IMG ALIGN=\"MIDDLE\" alt=\"${\\mu }_{870\\mu {\\rm{m}}}\\gt 30$\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/apjaa2662ieqn5.gif\"></IMG>. We compare the intrinsic size distribution of the strongly lensed sources to a similar number of unlensed DSFGs and find no significant differences in spite of a bias between the magnification and intrinsic source size. This may indicate that the true size distribution of DSFGs is relatively narrow. We use the source sizes to constrain the wavelength at which the dust optical depth is unity and find this wavelength to be correlated with the dust temperature. This correlation leads to discrepancies in dust mass estimates of a factor of two compared to estimates using a single value for this wavelength. We investigate the relationship between the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line and the far-infrared luminosity and find that the same correlation between the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]/<IMG ALIGN=\"MIDDLE\" alt=\"${L}_{{\\rm{FIR}}}$\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/apjaa2662ieqn6.gif\"></IMG>\u00a0ratio and <IMG ALIGN=\"MIDDLE\" alt=\"${{\\rm{\\Sigma }}}_{{\\rm{FIR}}}$\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/apjaa2662ieqn7.gif\"></IMG>\u00a0found for low-redshift star-forming galaxies applies to high-redshift galaxies and extends at least two orders of magnitude higher in <IMG ALIGN=\"MIDDLE\" alt=\"${{\\rm{\\Sigma }}}_{{\\rm{FIR}}}$\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/apjaa2662ieqn8.gif\"></IMG>. This lends further credence to the claim that the compactness of the IR-emitting region is the controlling parameter in establishing the \"[C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] deficit.\"</P> </div>\n    <!-- End abstract -->\n<!-- Start Export citation and abstract tools -->\n\t<p>\n\t\t<small>Export citation and abstract</small>\n\t\t<span class=\"btn-multi-block\">\n\t\t\t<a href=\"/export?articleId=0004-637X/826/2/112&doi=10.3847/0004-637X/826/2/112&exportFormat=iopexport_bib&exportType=abs&navsubmit=Export+abstract\" class=\"btn btn-primary wd-btn-cit-abs-bib\" title=\"Export BibTex\">BibTeX</a>\n\t\t\t<a href=\"/export?articleId=0004-637X/826/2/112&doi=10.3847/0004-637X/826/2/112&exportFormat=iopexport_ris&exportType=abs&navsubmit=Export+abstract\" class=\"btn btn-primary wd-btn-cit-abs-ris\" title=\"Export RIS\">RIS</a>\n\t\t</span>\n\t</p>\n<!-- End Export citation and abstract tools -->\n<!-- Start AAS Related Links -->\n<div class=\"reveal-container reveal-closed reveal-plus-icon bdt-1 mt-2 mb-2 wd-jnl-art-article-aas-related-links\">\n  <div class=\"replica-h3 mt-0\">\n    <a href=\"#\" class=\"reveal-trigger\" data-reveal-label-alt=\"Hide related links\">Related links</a>\n  </div>\n  <div class=\"reveal-content\">\n    <div class=\"article-meta\"> \n      <ul>\n      \t<li><a href=\"http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2016ApJ...826..112S\" target=\"_blank\">NASA ADS Record <span class=\"icon-newtab\"></span></a></li>\n      \t<li><a href=\"http://nedwww.ipac.caltech.edu/cgi-bin/nph-objsearch?refcode=2016ApJ...826..112S&search_type=Search \" target=\"_blank\">NED Objects <span class=\"icon-newtab\"></span></a></li>\n      \t<li><a href=\"http://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-ref?querymethod=bib&simbo=on&bibcode=2016ApJ...826..112S\" target=\"_blank\">Simbad Objects <span class=\"icon-newtab\"></span></a></li>\n      \t<li><a href=\"/journal/0004-637X/page/About%20Related%20Links\" target=\"_blank\">About Related Links</a></li>\n      \t</ul>\n    </div>\n  </div>\n</div>\n<!-- Start info bottom -->\n    <!-- End info bottom -->\n<!-- Start article full text -->\n\t<div xmlns:book=\"http://api.iop.org/Book/1.0/\" itemprop=\"articleBody\" class=\"wd-jnl-art-full-text article-text\">\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apjaa2662s1\" name=\"apjaa2662s1\">1.\u00a0INTRODUCTION</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>With the Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA) now in full operation, our understanding of dust-enshrouded star formation at high redshifts is advancing more rapidly than ever before. The most intense star formation in the universe takes place in dusty, star-forming galaxies (DSFGs) at high redshifts (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn9.gif\" alt=\"$z\\gt 1$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\gt 1</script></span></span>), creating new stars at rates of &gt;100\u20131000 <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn10.gif\" alt=\"${M}_{\\odot }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{M}_{\\odot }</script></span></span>  yr<sup>\u22121</sup> (see a recent review by Casey et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib18\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib18\">2014</a>). The otherwise high UV luminosity from massive, young stars in these galaxies is almost entirely reprocessed by interstellar dust, which absorbs the short-wavelength radiation and re-radiates it at far-infrared (FIR) and (sub)millimeter wavelengths. Although DSFGs represent a significant contribution to the comoving star formation rate density out to at least <em>z</em> = 4 (e.g., Chapman et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib19\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib19\">2005</a>; Casey et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib17\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib17\">2013</a>), producing a realistic population of DSFGs has long been a challenge for theoretical models of galaxy evolution (e.g., Baugh et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib4\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib4\">2005</a>; Dav\u00e9 et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib21\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib21\">2010</a>; Hayward et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib35\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib35\">2013</a>; Narayanan et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib54\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib54\">2015</a>).</p><p>Observations of these galaxies benefit from a strongly negative \"<em>K</em>-correction\" at submillimeter wavelengths (e.g., Blain &amp; Longair <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib9\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib9\">1993</a>), in which the dimming due to increased cosmological distance is countered by the rapidly rising dust spectral energy distribution (SED) at fixed observing wavelength. DSFGs were initially discovered in low-resolution (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn11.gif\" alt=\"$\\gt 10$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\gt 10</script></span></span>''), 850 <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn12.gif\" alt=\"$\\mu {\\rm{m}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mu {\\rm{m}}</script></span></span>\u00a0deep images (Smail et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib65\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib65\">1997</a>; Barger et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib3\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib3\">1998</a>; Hughes et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib42\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib42\">1998</a>), and high-resolution follow-up studies at submillimeter wavelengths remain challenging, as are observations at other wavelengths that do not benefit from the negative <em>K</em>-correction. One fairly straightforward method of gaining resolution is to target a sample of gravitationally lensed galaxies, such as those discovered by the South Pole Telescope (Vieira et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib75\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib75\">2010</a>; Carlstrom et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib14\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib14\">2011</a>; Mocanu et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib53\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib53\">2013</a>) or the <em>Herschel Space Observatory</em> (Negrello et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib55\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib55\">2010</a>; Wardlow et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib79\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib79\">2013</a>). Follow-up observations of these galaxies at FIR/submillimeter wavelengths, where they are brightest, with interferometers such as ALMA and the Submillimeter Array (SMA) have shown that the bulk of the brightest objects are consistent with strong gravitational lensing (e.g., Bussmann et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib12\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib12\">2013</a>; Hezaveh et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib37\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib37\">2013</a>; Vieira et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib76\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib76\">2013</a>). Lensed samples offer the opportunity to study DSFGs at higher resolution and using fainter observational diagnostics than otherwise possible (e.g., Swinbank et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib73\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib73\">2010</a>; Fu et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib29\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib29\">2012</a>; Bothwell et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib10\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib10\">2013</a>; Spilker et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib68\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib68\">2014</a>).</p><p>Taking advantage of gravitational lensing requires careful modeling to understand its effects. In this paper, we present lens models of a sample of 47 DSFGs discovered in South Pole Telescope data and observed by ALMA at ~0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />5 resolution. Hezaveh et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib37\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib37\">2013</a>) presented models of four sources which were spatially resolved at the ~1<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />5 resolution of the first data acquired for this project; here, we expand this work to include the completed data set, including all sources and array configurations. As in Hezaveh et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib37\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib37\">2013</a>), our models are performed in the Fourier plane native to the interferometer, and marginalized over several common calibration uncertainties. The resulting intrinsic source properties span a large range in luminosity, and we use these derived properties to explore the intrinsic size distribution of DSFGs, their dust SEDs, and the relation between the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] fine structure line and the FIR luminosity.</p><p>In Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjaa2662s2\">2</a>, we describe the selection criteria and ALMA observations. Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjaa2662s3\">3</a> describes our gravitational lens modeling technique, with the results of these models detailed in Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjaa2662s4\">4</a>. In Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjaa2662s5\">5</a>, we use these models to address selected topics of interest, including the intrinsic size distribution of DSFGs and the relationship between the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] fine structure line and the FIR luminosity. We conclude in Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjaa2662s6\">6</a>. Throughout this work, we assume a flat <em>WMAP</em>9 \u039bCDM cosmology, <em>h</em> = 0.693, <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn13.gif\" alt=\"${{\\rm{\\Omega }}}_{m}=0.286$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{{\\rm{\\Omega }}}_{m}=0.286</script></span></span>, and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn14.gif\" alt=\"${{\\rm{\\Omega }}}_{{\\rm{\\Lambda }}}=0.713$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{{\\rm{\\Omega }}}_{{\\rm{\\Lambda }}}=0.713</script></span></span> (Hinshaw et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib39\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib39\">2013</a>). We define the FIR luminosity <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn15.gif\" alt=\"${L}_{{\\rm{FIR}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{L}_{{\\rm{FIR}}}</script></span></span>\u00a0to be integrated over a rest-frame wavelength range of 42.5\u2013122.5 <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn16.gif\" alt=\"$\\mu {\\rm{m}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mu {\\rm{m}}</script></span></span>\u00a0(Helou et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib36\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib36\">1988</a>).</p></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apjaa2662s2\" name=\"apjaa2662s2\">2.\u00a0SAMPLE SELECTION AND OBSERVATIONS</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>The selection criteria used to generate the SPT DSFG sample are described in detail by Wei\u00df et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib80\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib80\">2013</a>). Briefly, sources were selected to have dust-like spectral indices between 1.4 and 2 mm (i.e., <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn17.gif\" alt=\"${S}_{1.4\\mathrm{mm}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{S}_{1.4\\mathrm{mm}}</script></span></span>/<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn18.gif\" alt=\"${S}_{2\\mathrm{mm}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{S}_{2\\mathrm{mm}}</script></span></span>  <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn19.gif\" alt=\"$\\gt \\,1.7;$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\gt \\,1.7;</script></span></span> Mocanu et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib53\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib53\">2013</a>). Further selection criteria remove synchrotron-dominated and low-redshift (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn20.gif\" alt=\"$z\\lt 0.1$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\lt 0.1</script></span></span>) contaminant sources. Redshifts for some of the SPT DSFGs are presented in Strandet et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib71\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib71\">2016</a>). Optical and near-infrared spectroscopic redshifts of the foreground lenses, where available, will be presented in K. M. Rotermund et al. (2016, in preparation). Finally, we make use of optical and infrared imaging data obtained from a variety of facilities, including the <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> (<em>HST</em>), Very Large Telescope, <em>Magellan</em>-Baade telescope, and <em>Spitzer</em>/IRAC.</p><p>To refine the coarse SPT positions, each source was observed at higher spatial resolution to improve the positional accuracy, typically at 870 <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn21.gif\" alt=\"$\\mu {\\rm{m}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mu {\\rm{m}}</script></span></span>\u00a0using the Large Apex BOlometer CAmera (LABOCA) or at 1.3 mm using the SMA. From this catalog, we selected 47 bright sources which could be placed into four groups of targets that lie within 15\u00b0 of each other on the sky in order to share calibrator sources. The targets are listed in Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjaa2662t1\">1</a>. In Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaa2662f1\">1</a>, we compare the objects in the subsample observed by ALMA with all SPT sources and with the <em>Herschel</em>-selected objects observed by Bussmann et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib12\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib12\">2013</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib13\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib13\">2015</a>).</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apjaa2662f1\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjaa2662f1\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662f1_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 1.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 1.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662f1_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 1.</strong>\u00a0Comparison of the subsample of SPT sources observed by ALMA to all SPT sources and the <em>Herschel</em>-selected samples of Bussmann et al. (<a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib12\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib12\">2013</a>, <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib13\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib13\">2015</a>). Note that <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn22.gif\" alt=\"${S}_{870\\mu {\\rm{m}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{S}_{870\\mu {\\rm{m}}}</script></span></span> shown in this figure is derived from single-dish LABOCA measurements for the SPT sources. Single-dish photometry is not available for the <em>Herschel</em> sources, and so these points are derived from interferometric (SMA or ALMA) observations only and may underestimate the true total flux density; see Section <a class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjaa2662s4-2\">4.2</a>. Top: the subsample of SPT sources observed by ALMA was selected to have high <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn23.gif\" alt=\"${S}_{1.4\\mathrm{mm}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{S}_{1.4\\mathrm{mm}}</script></span></span>, and spans most of the range of <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn24.gif\" alt=\"${S}_{870\\mu {\\rm{m}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{S}_{870\\mu {\\rm{m}}}</script></span></span> seen in the full sample. Bottom: flux density\u2014FIR color diagram for SPT- and <em>Herschel</em>- selected DSFGs (Bussmann et al. <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib12\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib12\">2013</a>, <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib13\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib13\">2015</a>). The SPT sources are redder on average, and at higher redshift (e.g., Wei\u00df et al. <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib80\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib80\">2013</a>; B\u00e9thermin et al. <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib6\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib6\">2015</a>), largely due to their longer selection wavelength.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apjaa2662f1\" href=\"/0004-637X/826/2/112/downloadFigure/figure/apjaa2662f1\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apjaa2662f1\" href=\"/0004-637X/826/2/112/downloadHRFigure/figure/apjaa2662f1\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><div tabindex=\"-1\" align=\"center\">3.0700</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody></table><p><small>\n<p><strong>Notes.</strong> Positions listed correspond to the ALMA phase center. Source redshifts are given in Wei\u00df et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib80\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib80\">2013</a>) and Strandet et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib71\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib71\">2016</a>). Lens redshifts are given in K. M. Rotermund (et al. 2016, in preparation). Note that both LABOCA and ALMA flux densities are measured at 870 <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn26.gif\" alt=\"$\\mu {\\rm{m}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mu {\\rm{m}}</script></span></span>.</p>\n<a name=\"apjaa2662fn1\" id=\"apjaa2662fn1\"></a><sup> a</sup>Total flux density in the ALMA image; see Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjaa2662s4-2\">4.2</a>. Flux densities include 10% absolute calibration uncertainties.\n<a name=\"apjaa2662fn2\" id=\"apjaa2662fn2\"></a><sup> b</sup>Source appears to be lensed by a large group or cluster and cannot be modeled; these sources are shown in Appendix <xref summary=\"e shown in Appendix B.\">B</xref>.\n<a name=\"apjaa2662fn3\" id=\"apjaa2662fn3\"></a><sup> c</sup>SPT2300-51 is undetected by ALMA; the listed ALMA flux is derived from a ~4<em>\u03c3</em> source outside the primary beam half-power radius.\n</small></p><p class=\"franklin fs-16\">\n\t\t\tDownload table as:\u00a0\n            <span class=\"btn-multi-block\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-ascii\" href=\"/0004-637X/826/2/112/suppdata/apjaa2662t1_ascii.txt?doi=10.3847/0004-637X/826/2/112\" target=\"_blank\">ASCII</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-typeset typeset-table-img\" href=\"/0004-637X/826/2/112/suppdata/apjaa2662t1_lr.gif\" target=\"_blank\">Typeset image</a></span></p></div><p>These 47 SPT sources were observed by ALMA at 870 <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn27.gif\" alt=\"$\\mu {\\rm{m}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mu {\\rm{m}}</script></span></span>\u00a0as part of Cycle 0 program 2011.0.00958.S (PI D. Marrone). The ALMA observations were carried out in eight sessions from 2011 November to 2012 August and are summarized in Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjaa2662t2\">2</a>. Given the limited number of antennas available at the beginning of Cycle 0 (minimum 14), each group of sources was observed with two different array configurations, corresponding to approximately 0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />5 and 1<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />5 resolution, to provide better sampling of the <em>uv</em>-plane. Over the series of observations, the number of antennas increased (up to 25), providing greater sensitivity in later observations. Additional sources with precisely known positions from the International Celestial Reference Frame (ICRF; Ma et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib49\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib49\">1998</a>) were observed to verify the astrometric and antenna baseline solutions. Each source was observed for 60\u201390 s per array configuration. The total observing time for all calibrators and science targets was 9.4 hr.</p><div tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"apjaa2662t2\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\"><p><b>Table 2.</b>\u00a0\nObservational Summary\n</p><table cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjaa2662t2\" data-toolbar-img=\"/0004-637X/826/2/112/suppdata/apjaa2662t2_lr.gif\" src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />2</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">\u00a0</td>\n<td 16</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">0.8</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">Callisto</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">16</td>\n<td align=\"center\">0.31</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\"\u00d7\">0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />5 <b>&#x00d7;</b> 0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />6</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">SPT2300-51\u2013SPT0128-51</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">2012 May 22</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">1.4</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">Neptune</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">19</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">0.40</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\"\u00d7\">0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />4 <b>&#x00d7;</b> 0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />5</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">\u00a0</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">2012 Aug 13</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">1.7</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">Neptune</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">25</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">0.21</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\"\u00d7\">0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />5 <b>&#x00d7;</b> 0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />6</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody></table><p><small>\n<p><strong>Notes.</strong></p>\n<a name=\"apjaa2662fn4\" id=\"apjaa2662fn4\"></a><sup> a</sup>Total observation time includes overheads.\n<a name=\"apjaa2662fn5\" id=\"apjaa2662fn5\"></a><sup> b</sup>Sensitivity and beam size are averages for all science targets in each track.\n</small></p><p class=\"franklin fs-16\">\n\t\t\tDownload table as:\u00a0\n            <span class=\"btn-multi-block\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-ascii\" href=\"/0004-637X/826/2/112/suppdata/apjaa2662t2_ascii.txt?doi=10.3847/0004-637X/826/2/112\" target=\"_blank\">ASCII</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-typeset typeset-table-img\" href=\"/0004-637X/826/2/112/suppdata/apjaa2662t2_lr.gif\" target=\"_blank\">Typeset image</a></span></p></div><p>Four basebands, each processing 2 GHz of telescope bandwidth, were centered near 336.8, 338.8, 348.8, and 350.8 GHz. The correlator was configured to provide 128 channels of 15.6 MHz width for each baseband. Bandpass calibration was performed by observing a bright quasar at the beginning of each track. Time-dependent amplitude and phase variations were calibrated using several quasars near (typically within <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn28.gif\" alt=\"$\\lt 5^\\circ $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\lt 5^\\circ</script></span></span> of) the science targets. The flux scale was determined at the beginning of each track using an available solar system object or quasar with a recently determined flux density, as detailed in Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjaa2662t2\">2</a>. This flux scale is estimated to be correct to within 10%, although we allow an amplitude re-scaling between the two observations of each group of sources in our modeling (see Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjaa2662s3\">3</a>). We estimate the noise on each visibility measurement by calculating the scatter after differencing successive visibilities on the same baseline, baseband, and polarization. After calibration, the data from each track were combined and imaged using Briggs weighting (robust parameter <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn29.gif\" alt=\"$=\\,-0.5$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">=\\,-0.5</script></span></span>). This weighting represents a compromise which somewhat favors higher resolution at the expense of sensitivity.</p><p>In four objects (SPT0125-47, SPT0125-50, SPT2103-60, SPT2354-58), we serendipitously detected a spectral feature in the ALMA data. As we consider only models of the continuum emission in this work, for these sources, we exclude the spectral window containing the spectral line.</p><p>Another four objects (SPT0550-53, SPT0551-50, SPT2351-57, SPT2353-50) appear to be lensed by galaxy groups or clusters. <em>HST</em> imaging shows numerous galaxies in the vicinity of the 870 <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn30.gif\" alt=\"$\\mu {\\rm{m}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mu {\\rm{m}}</script></span></span>\u00a0emission. Images of these sources are shown in Appendix <xref summary=\"e shown in Appendix B. The ALMA measureme\">B</xref>. The ALMA measurements show only single images, and the ALMA field of view does not encompass the expected locations of counterimages. For these sources, the lensing geometry cannot be constrained by the ALMA data alone. Beyond counting them among the sources identified as lensed, we ignore them for the remainder of this paper.</p><p>Images of the sources we model in this paper, overlaid on the best-available near-IR or optical imaging, are shown in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaa2662f2\">2</a>.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apjaa2662f2\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjaa2662f2\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662f2a_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 2.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 2.</strong>\u00a0Images and lens models for all sources modeled in this work. Left: ALMA 870 <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn31.gif\" alt=\"$\\mu {\\rm{m}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mu {\\rm{m}}</script></span></span>\u00a0emission (blue contours) overlaid on the best-available optical/NIR image (grayscale) for each source. Contours are drawn at 10, 30, \u22ef% of the peak value. The synthesized beam is indicated in the lower left corner. For some objects, we also show images of the 870 <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn32.gif\" alt=\"$\\mu {\\rm{m}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mu {\\rm{m}}</script></span></span>\u00a0emission which highlight the resolved structure present in the data, created by imaging only the data from the longest baselines (green contours; see Appendix <xref summary=\"tours; see Appendix A for details). Grays\">A</xref> for details). Grayscale images are logarithmically scaled to emphasize the objects detected. Fitted lens positions are shown with navy diamonds; sources with multiple lenses are labeled as in Table <a class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjaa2662t3\">3</a>. In panels with a large field of view, the ALMA primary beam half-power radius is indicated with a dotted line; for the other objects, the primary beam correction at the center of the image is given in the middle panel as the scale factor before the noise level in mJy. Middle: model dirty images (grayscale), with residual contours (blue) in steps of \u00b12, 4, \u22ef<em>\u03c3</em>. Right: fully resolved best-fit model images (blue), with caustics shown in green. The inset of each panel shows a zoomed-in view of the source-plane emission where the size of the inset is given in the lower-center of each panel. Multiple sources are labeled as in Table <a class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjaa2662t4\">4</a>.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apjaa2662f2d\" href=\"/0004-637X/826/2/112/downloadFigure/figure/apjaa2662f2d\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apjaa2662f2d\" href=\"/0004-637X/826/2/112/downloadHRFigure/figure/apjaa2662f2d\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apjaa2662s3\" name=\"apjaa2662s3\">3.\u00a0VISIBILITY-BASED LENS MODELING</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>When modeling the effects of gravitational lensing, many methods perform the fitting procedure directly on observed images of the lensed emission. However, ALMA does not directly image the sky emission; rather, it measures the Fourier components of the sky emission at a range of two-dimensional spatial frequencies. Inverting these visibilities leads to correlated noise in the resulting images which can introduce bias into later measurements. Instead, a better option is to model the visibilities directly, where the noise and measurement are well understood. Modeling in the <em>uv</em>-plane also allows us to model and account for residual calibration errors, including improper antenna delay calibrations and mismatched absolute flux scales from observations taken on different days. Our lens modeling procedure is based on the work of Hezaveh et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib37\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib37\">2013</a>; see also Bussmann et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib11\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib11\">2012</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib12\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib12\">2013</a> for a similar technique).</p><p>The lens mass profile is represented by one or more Singular Isothermal Ellipsoids (SIEs), with lensing deflections derived by Kormann et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib47\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib47\">1994</a>). The SIE is parameterized by its two-dimensional location relative to the phase center (<em>x</em><sub><em>L</em></sub>, <em>y</em><sub><em>L</em></sub>), the lens strength in the form of the angular Einstein radius <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn33.gif\" alt=\"${\\theta }_{E,L}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\theta }_{E,L}</script></span></span>, ellipticity <em>e</em><sub><em>L</em></sub>, and position angle of the major axis <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn34.gif\" alt=\"${\\phi }_{L}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\phi }_{L}</script></span></span> in degrees east of north. In some cases, the data also favor the existence of an external tidal shear (<em>\u03b3</em>), with deflections calculated as in Keeton et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib46\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib46\">2000</a>; we have redefined the shear position angle, <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn35.gif\" alt=\"${\\phi }_{\\gamma }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\phi }_{\\gamma }</script></span></span>, to match the convention used here for <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn36.gif\" alt=\"${\\phi }_{L}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\phi }_{L}</script></span></span>). Background source emission and any unlensed sources are represented as one or more unresolved point sources (with position <em>x</em><sub><em>S</em></sub> and <em>y</em><sub><em>S</em></sub>, and flux density <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn37.gif\" alt=\"${S}_{870\\mu {\\rm{m}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{S}_{870\\mu {\\rm{m}}}</script></span></span> as free parameters) or S\u00e9rsic profiles (S\u00e9rsic <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib63\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib63\">1968</a>; with position <em>x</em><sub><em>S</em></sub> and <em>y</em><sub><em>S</em></sub>, flux density <em>S</em><sub>870<em>\u03bc</em>m</sub>, S\u00e9rsic index <em>n</em><sub><em>S</em></sub>, half-light radius <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn38.gif\" alt=\"${r}_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{r}_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span>, axis ratio <em>b</em><sub><em>S</em></sub>/<em>a</em><sub><em>S</em></sub>, and position angle <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn39.gif\" alt=\"${\\phi }_{S}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\phi }_{S}</script></span></span> as free parameters). Note that a S\u00e9rsic index <em>n</em> = 4 corresponds to a de Vaucouleurs (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib23\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib23\">1953</a>) profile, <em>n</em> = 1 an exponential disk, and <em>n</em> = 0.5 a Gaussian light profile (in Hezaveh et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib37\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib37\">2013</a>, all sources were modeled as circularly symmetric Gaussian profiles). For lensed sources, we define the location of the source to be relative to the primary lens in the model, while for unlensed sources it is defined relative to the ALMA phase center. Within the framework we have developed, any of these lens and source parameters may be held fixed during fitting, and loose flat priors may be used. We use available optical/NIR imaging to guide the models (e.g., a single lens versus multiple lenses), but the positions of galaxies identified in these images are not otherwise used, except for singly imaged sources for which the ALMA data alone are not sufficiently constraining.</p><p>To reproduce the information present in our high signal-to-noise ratio measurements, and to represent realistic calibration uncertainties, our modeling must be more flexible than that used in previous work (e.g., Bussmann et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib12\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib12\">2013</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib13\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib13\">2015</a>; Hezaveh et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib37\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib37\">2013</a>). For example, because we are jointly modeling multiple data sets taken several months apart (see Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjaa2662t2\">2</a>), small differences in absolute calibration or atmospheric conditions between epochs could be translated into false shifts in parameters. To address this possibility, we allow for a multiplicative amplitude re-scaling factor and an astrometric offset between the two tracks. We also calibrate uncorrected antenna-based phase errors using the procedure described in Hezaveh et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib37\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib37\">2013</a>). These phase errors may be attributed to uncompensated atmospheric delays or imprecisely known antenna positions. These phase errors are generally small, except in the two 2011 November tracks, which were observed prior to antenna baseline solutions being incorporated into the reduction pipeline. The phase errors and astrometric shifts derived from this procedure are consistent with those found for the ICRF sources that we added to our observations to test the calibration and astrometry of the data.</p><p>We employ a Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) fitting procedure, using the <tt>emcee</tt> (Foreman-Mackey et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib28\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib28\">2013</a>) code to sample the posterior probability function. At each point in parameter space, we generate a model image from a given set of lens and source parameters, including the flux scaling and astrometric offsets mentioned above. We then invert this image to the Fourier plane and measure the modeled visibilities at the <em>uv</em> coordinates of each data set. The quality of fit is calculated using the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn40.gif\" alt=\"${\\chi }^{2}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\chi }^{2}</script></span></span> metric. When comparing models of the same source with different numbers of free parameters, we use the Deviance Information Criterion (DIC; Spiegelhalter et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib66\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib66\">2002</a>) for model selection. The DIC determines, for example, whether including an additional source-plane component is justified.</p><p>The code used to generate all of the models in this work, along with example usage scripts, is available at <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"webref\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://github.com/jspilker/visilens\">https://github.com/jspilker/visilens</a>.</p></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apjaa2662s4\" name=\"apjaa2662s4\">4.\u00a0RESULTS</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>Images of each system along with the best-fit image- and source-plane models are shown in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaa2662f2\">2</a>. These models are briefly described in Appendix <xref summary=\"scribed in Appendix A. Summaries of the p\">A</xref>. Summaries of the properties of the lenses and sources are provided in Tables <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjaa2662t3\">3</a> and <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjaa2662t4\">4</a>, respectively. These tables are available in machine-readable format at <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"webref\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"http://justinspilker.com/lensmodels\">justinspilker.com/lensmodels</a>.</p><div tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"apjaa2662t3\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\"><p><b>Table 0.01</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">2.19 \u00b1 0.02</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">0.758 \u00b1 0.005</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" Lens positions (<em>x</em><sub><em>L</em></sub>, <em>y</em><sub><em>L</em></sub>) are relative to the ALMA phase center, shown for each source in Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjaa2662t1\">1</a>. Also listed are the lens Einstein radius (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn44.gif\" alt=\"${\\theta }_{E,L}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\theta }_{E,L}</script></span></span>, ellipticity (<em>e</em><sub><em>L</em></sub>), and position angle (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn45.gif\" alt=\"${\\phi }_{L}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\phi }_{L}</script></span></span>). For sources which require an external shear component, the shear strength (<em>\u03b3</em>) and position angle (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn46.gif\" alt=\"${\\phi }_{\\gamma }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\phi }_{\\gamma }</script></span></span>) are also given. Quantities without uncertainties have been fixed to the values shown during fitting.</p>\n<p>(A machine-readable version of this table is available at justinspilker.com/lensmodels.)</p>\n</small></p><p class=\"franklin fs-16\">\n\t\t\tDownload table as:\u00a0\n            <span class=\"btn-multi-block\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary align=\"center\">2.9 \u00b1 0.1</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody></table><p><small>\n<p><strong>Note.</strong> For lensed sources (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn51.gif\" alt=\"${\\mu }_{870\\mu {\\rm{m}}}\\gt 1$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\mu }_{870\\mu {\\rm{m}}}\\gt 1</script></span></span>), source positions are relative to the first lens listed for each source in Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjaa2662t3\">3</a>. For unlensed sources, positions are relative to the ALMA phase center given in Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjaa2662t1\">1</a>. Quantities without uncertainties have been fixed during fitting to the values listed. Sources without a listed size are unresolved (point-like) in the ALMA data.</p>\n<a name=\"apjaa2662fn6\" id=\"apjaa2662fn6\"></a><sup> a</sup>Parameters derived under the assumption of fixed lens Einstein radius; see Appendix <xref summary=\"adius; see Appendix A.\">A</xref>.(A machine-readable version of this table is available at justinspilker.com/lensmodels.)\n</small></p><p class=\"franklin fs-16\">\n\t\t\tDownload table as:\u00a0\n            <span class=\"btn-multi-block\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-ascii\" href=\"/0004-637X/826/2/112/suppdata/apjaa2662t4_ascii.txt?doi=10.3847/0004-637X/826/2/112\" target=\"_blank\">ASCII</a>Typeset images: <a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-typeset-multiple typeset-table-img\" href=\"/0004-637X/826/2/112/suppdata/apjaa2662t4_lr.gif\" target=\"_blank\">1</a> <a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-typeset-multiple typeset-table-img\" href=\"/0004-637X/826/2/112/suppdata/apjaa2662t4a_lr.gif\" target=\"_blank\">2</a> </span></p></div><h3 id=\"apjaa2662s4-1\" name=\"apjaa2662s4-1\">4.1.\u00a0Basic Lens Model Properties</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>As expected, a large fraction of the 47 fields observed by ALMA are consistent with strongly lensed systems\u2014for 38 sources (81%), strong gravitational lensing is the most plausible explanation for the ALMA emission. Of these, 4 sources (11% of the strongly lensed sources) appear to be lensed by large groups or clusters of galaxies. An additional 8 sources (17%) appear to be unlensed or weakly lensed. Of these sources, 2 are co-located (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn52.gif\" alt=\"$\\lt 0\\buildrel{\\prime\\prime}\\over{.} 5$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\lt 0\\buildrel{\\prime\\prime}\\over{.} 5</script></span></span>) with objects also detected in the optical or near-infrared but do not appear to be lensed, 2 more are within 3'' of optical/NIR counterparts and are likely either weakly lensed background sources or unlensed sources with undetected optical counterparts, while the remaining 4 sources do not appear to be closely associated with any objects detected in the best-available optical/NIR imaging. The final source, SPT2300-51, was undetected by ALMA at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn53.gif\" alt=\"$\\gt 5\\sigma $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\gt 5\\sigma</script></span></span> significance within the ALMA primary beam half-power radius and was determined to be a spurious detection in the LABOCA follow-up of SPT sources; this source is shown in Appendix <xref summary=\"s shown in Appendix A.\">A</xref>.</p><p>Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaa2662f3\">3</a> summarizes some key parameters of the lens models. The left panel shows the distribution of Einstein radii for the strongly lensed sources, where we have added the Einstein radii of systems with multiple lenses in quadrature. We find a median Einstein radius of 0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />64, with the distribution rising until approximately the half-resolution radius of our data. The minimum discernible Einstein radius is dependent on the lensing geometry and properties of the background sources. A multiply-imaged source lensed by a galaxy with an Einstein radius less than approximately the half-resolution radius of our data would be difficult to discern, because the multiple images of strongly lensed systems are generally separated by ~2 Einstein radii. The same restriction does not apply for singly imaged sources, but in this case the background source must be sufficiently extended for the lens to induce noticeable distortion in the image. The fact that the distribution of Einstein radii rises until the half-resolution radius of our data may indicate that higher-resolution observations will reveal that some of the sources which are unresolved in the current data may also be gravitationally lensed. A similar median Einstein radius of ~0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />6 was found for the <em>Herschel</em>-selected sample of Bussmann et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib12\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib12\">2013</a>). This may indicate that the two surveys probe a similar population of lens galaxies, in spite of the difference in background source properties (e.g., Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaa2662f1\">1</a>). We defer a more thorough discussion of the lens galaxies to a future work.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apjaa2662f3\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjaa2662f3\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662f3_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 3.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 3.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662f3_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 3.</strong>\u00a0Left: distribution of Einstein radii for the strongly lensed SPT sources. For objects with multiple lenses, the Einstein radii of the individual lens galaxies have been added in quadrature. Middle: distribution of <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn54.gif\" alt=\"${\\mu }_{870\\mu {\\rm{m}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\mu }_{870\\mu {\\rm{m}}}</script></span></span> for all modeled sources. For sources with multiple components, the flux density-weighted mean magnification is shown. Right: source magnification as a function of apparent LABOCA flux density.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apjaa2662f3\" href=\"/0004-637X/826/2/112/downloadFigure/figure/apjaa2662f3\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apjaa2662f3\" href=\"/0004-637X/826/2/112/downloadHRFigure/figure/apjaa2662f3\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><p>The center panel of Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaa2662f3\">3</a> shows the distribution of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn55.gif\" alt=\"${\\mu }_{870\\mu {\\rm{m}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\mu }_{870\\mu {\\rm{m}}}</script></span></span> for the SPT sources, with a median magnification of 5.5 for all sources, or 6.3 for the strongly lensed subset alone. This is somewhat higher than the median magnification of 4.6 found by Bussmann et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib12\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib12\">2013</a>) in a study of <em>Herschel</em>-selected objects. The magnification distribution for the SPT sources also appears to contain a tail to higher magnifications compared to the <em>Herschel</em> sample; for approximately 30% of the strongly lensed sources, the best-fit magnifications are <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn56.gif\" alt=\"${\\mu }_{870\\mu {\\rm{m}}}\\gt 10$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\mu }_{870\\mu {\\rm{m}}}\\gt 10</script></span></span>.</p><p>The fraction of strongly lensed sources is expected to vary with the flux density threshold used to create the source catalogs. Lower flux density limits will include a higher proportion of unlensed sources. Equivalently, the median magnification of an observed sample of objects is a function of the flux density threshold. The right panel of Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaa2662f3\">3</a> illustrates this effect: on average, apparently brighter sources are magnified more highly. This effect is also apparent in the brighter <em>Herschel</em> sample studied by Bussmann et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib12\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib12\">2013</a>), in which at least 21 of 30 sources are strongly lensed, compared to a fainter sample described in Bussmann et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib13\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib13\">2015</a>), in which only 6 of 29 sources are strongly lensed. This difference is likely due to the shape of the submillimeter number counts, which drop steeply for sources with intrinsic <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn57.gif\" alt=\"${S}_{870\\mu {\\rm{m}}}\\gtrsim 8.5$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{S}_{870\\mu {\\rm{m}}}\\gtrsim 8.5</script></span></span> mJy (Karim et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib45\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib45\">2013</a>; Simpson et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib64\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib64\">2015</a>).</p></div><h3 id=\"apjaa2662s4-2\" name=\"apjaa2662s4-2\">4.2.\u00a0Flux Recovery</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>Every source targeted was detected, with the exception of SPT2300-51 (this source was determined to be false after it was included in the ALMA sample). Each source had previously been observed at the same frequency using LABOCA on APEX, a single-dish bolometer camera with the same primary beam size as the ALMA data. By comparing the 870 <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn58.gif\" alt=\"$\\mu {\\rm{m}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mu {\\rm{m}}</script></span></span>\u00a0flux density measured by LABOCA to that recovered in the ALMA data, we can test whether or not significant flux has been resolved out by ALMA due to limited coverage of the <em>uv</em>-plane. This could occur if the sources have structure extended on scales greater than the largest scale recoverable by the data, or if additional sources are present in the maps which are too faint to have been detected individually or are outside the primary beam.</p><p>Almost all of the sources in our sample are significantly resolved in the ALMA data. To estimate the total flux density present in the ALMA maps, we first image the data using a taper in the <em>uv</em>-plane at 50 k<em>\u03bb</em>, corresponding to a resolution of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn59.gif\" alt=\"$\\gtrsim 4$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\gtrsim 4</script></span></span>''. This ensures that we measure a value as close as possible to the true single-dish \"zero-spacing\" flux density. We then CLEAN the images to a 3<em>\u03c3</em> threshold and correct for the response of the primary beam. The total ALMA flux is then defined as the sum of the CLEAN components, in order to avoid the need to define an aperture over which to measure the total flux density. If our sources were unresolved on scales <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn60.gif\" alt=\"$\\lt 50$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\lt 50</script></span></span> k<em>\u03bb</em>, then this would be equivalent to reporting the maximum pixel value in the images; in practice, many of our sources still show some structure on these scales.</p><p>In the left panel of Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaa2662f4\">4</a>, we compare the total flux densities of the ALMA sources determined in this way to the LABOCA measurements (Wei\u00df et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib80\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib80\">2013</a>). Note that we have made no effort to correct for the different bandwidths of the two instruments (8 versus ~60 GHz). We recover a median of (91 \u00b1 24)% of the LABOCA flux density, consistent within the mutual absolute flux scaling uncertainties (~10% for both instruments). Meanwhile, the middle panel of Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaa2662f4\">4</a> shows no clear trend in the fraction of flux recovered as a function of LABOCA flux density. These plots suggest that, in general, the ALMA data do not resolve out significant extended emission or hide a large population of sources too faint to detect individually. Hodge et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa2662bib40\" id=\"fnref-apjaa2662bib40\">2013</a>) reached a similar conclusion using ALMA to image a large sample of unlensed 870 <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn61.gif\" alt=\"$\\mu {\\rm{m}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mu {\\rm{m}}</script></span></span>-selected sources discovered by LABOCA in the Extended <em>Chandra</em> Deep Field-South. The sample of SPT DSFGs observed in this work shows a better degree of consistency between the ALMA and LABOCA flux densities, which may be due to the fact that the SPT-selected sources are apparently brighter. Indeed, the brightest sources studied by Hodge et al. correspond to the faintest sources in the present sample.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apjaa2662f4\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjaa2662f4\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662f4_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 4.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 4.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662f4_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 4.</strong>\u00a0Extent to which flux densities derived from ALMA, LABOCA, and the lens models agree; see Section <a class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjaa2662s4-2\">4.2</a> for details. In all three panels, solid lines indicate perfect agreement between the flux density measurements being compared. Left: the ALMA data recover a median of 91% of the single-dish flux density measured by LABOCA, indicated by the dashed line. Middle: no clear trend is seen in the fraction of flux detected by ALMA as a function of LABOCA flux density. Right: the lens models of all sources contain a median of 102% of the total ALMA flux density.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apjaa2662f4\" href=\"/0004-637X/826/2/112/downloadFigure/figure/apjaa2662f4\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apjaa2662f4\" href=\"/0004-637X/826/2/112/downloadHRFigure/figure/apjaa2662f4\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><p>We also test the extent to which the total ALMA flux densities agree with the total flux densities inferred from the lens models. In this case, we define the total model flux density as the sum over all components of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/826/2/112/Full/apjaa2662ieqn62.gif\" alt=\"${S}_{870\\mu {\\rm{m}}}\\times {\\mu }_{870\\mu {\\rm{m}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{S}_{870\\mu {\\rm{m}}}\\times {\\mu }_{870\\mu {\\rm{m}}}</script></span></span>. This is shown in the right panel of Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaa2662f4\">4</a>. The models contain a median of 102% of the total ALMA flux densities, indicating that no significant sources of emission remain unaccounted for by the models. As the residual maps generated by the best-fit models shown in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaa2662f2\">2</a> show no significant remaining peaks, this is unsurprising.</p></div><h3 id=\"apjaa2662s4-3\" name=\"apjaa2662s4-3\">4.3.\u00a0Multiplicity in the SPT Sample</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>Several high-resolution ALMA follow-up studies of submillimeter sources originally detected in low-resolution, single-dish surveys have concluded that a significant fraction of the sources break up into multiple components when observed at higher resolution. In the ALESS program, Hodge et al.
